driftwood caught his attentio and his eye nfollowed it dow the current how slowly it appeared to move what nsluggish stream nhe closed his eye i orde to fix his last thought upo his wife and nchildre the wate touched to gold by the early su the brooding nmists unde the bank at some distance dow the stream the fort the nsoldiers the piece of drift all had distracted him and now he became nconscious of new disturbance striking through the thought of his dea none wa sound which he could neithe ignore no understand sharp ndistinct metallic percussio like the stroke of blacksmith hamme nupo the anvil it had the same ringing quality he wondered what it nwas and whethe immeasurably distant o nea by it seemed both it nrecurrence wa regula but a slow a the tolling of death knell he nawaited each stroke with impatience and he knew not why apprehensio nthe interval of silence grew progressively longe the delay became nmaddening with thei greate infrequency the sound increased i nstrength and sharpness they hurt his ea like the thrust of knife he nfeared he would shriek what he heard wa the ticking of his watch nhe unclosed his eye and saw agai the wate below him if could free nmy hand he thought might throw off the noose and spring into the nstream by diving could evade the bullet and swimming vigorously nreach the bank take to the wood and get away home my home thank god ni a yet outside thei line my wife and little one are still beyond nthe invade farthest advance na these thought which have here to be set dow i word were flashed ninto the doomed ma brai rathe tha evolved from it the captai nnodded to the sergeant the sergeant stepped aside nii npeyto farquha wa well to do plante of a old and highly respected nalabama family being slave owne and like othe slave owner npoliticia he wa naturally a original secessionist and ardently ndevoted to the southe cause circumstance of a imperious nature nwhich it is unnecessary to relate here had prevented him from taking nservice with the gallant army that had fought the disastrous campaign nending with the fall of corinth and he chafed unde the inglorious nrestraint longing fo the release of his energy the large life of nthe soldie the opportunity fo distinctio that opportunity he felt nwould come a it come to all i wa time meanwhile he did what he ncould no service wa too humble fo him to perform i aid of the south nno adventure too perilous fo him to undertake if consistent with the ncharacte of civilia who wa at heart soldie and who i good nfaith and without too much qualificatio assented to at least part of nthe frankly villainous dictum that all is fai i love and wa none evening while farquha and his wife were sitting o rustic bench nnea the entrance to his ground gray clad soldie rode up to the ngate and asked fo drink of wate mr farquha wa only too happy to nserve him with he ow white hand while she wa fetching the wate he nhusband approached the dusty horsema and inquired eagerly fo news from nthe front the yank are repairing the railroad said the ma and are getting nready fo anothe advance they have reached the owl creek bridge put nit i orde and built stockade o the north bank the commandant ha nissued a orde which is posted everywhere declaring that any civilia ncaught interfering with the railroad it bridge tunnel o train nwill be summarily hanged saw the orde how fa is it to the owl creek bridge farquha asked about thirty mile is there no force o this side the creek only picket post half mile out o the railroad and single nsentinel at this end of the bridge suppose ma civilia and student of hanging should elude the npicket post and perhaps get the bette of the sentinel said farquha nsmiling what could he accomplish nthe soldie reflected wa there month ago he replied nobserved that the flood of last winte had lodged great quantity of ndriftwood against the woode pie at this end of the bridge it is now ndry and would bu like tow nthe lady had now brought the wate which the soldie drank he thanked nhe ceremoniously bowed to he husband and rode away a hou late nafte nightfall he repassed the plantatio going northward i the ndirectio from which he had come he wa federal scout niii na peyto farquha fell straight downward through the bridge he lost nconsciousness and wa a one already dead from this state he wa nawakened age late it seemed to him by the pai of sharp pressure nupo his throat followed by sense of suffocatio kee poignant nagonies seemed to shoot from his neck downward through every fibre of nhis body and limb these pain appeared to flash along well defined nlines of ramificatio and to beat with a inconceivably rapid nperiodicity they seemed like stream of pulsating fire heating him to na intolerable temperature a to his head he wa conscious of nothing nbut feeling of fulness of congestio these sensation were nunaccompanied by thought the intellectual part of his nature wa nalready effaced he had powe only to feel and feeling wa torment he nwas conscious of motio encompassed i luminous cloud of which he nwas now merely the fiery heart without material substance he swung nthrough unthinkable arc of oscillatio like vast pendulum the all nat once with terrible suddenness the light about him shot upward with nthe noise of loud plash frightful roaring wa i his ear and all nwas cold and dark the powe of thought wa restored he knew that the nrope had broke and he had falle into the stream there wa no nadditional strangulatio the noose about his neck wa already nsuffocating him and kept the wate from his lung to die of hanging at nthe bottom of rive the idea seemed to him ludicrous he opened his neyes i the darkness and saw above him gleam of light but how ndistant how inaccessible he wa still sinking fo the light became nfainte and fainte until it wa mere glimme the it bega to grow nand brighte and he knew that he wa rising toward the surface knew it nwith reluctance fo he wa now very comfortable to be hanged and ndrowned he thought that is not so bad but do not wish to be shot nno will not be shot that is not fai nhe wa not conscious of a effort but sharp pai i his wrist napprised him that he wa trying to free his hand he gave the struggle nhis attentio a a idle might observe the feat of juggle without ninterest i the outcome what splendid effort what magnificent what nsuperhuma strength ah that wa fine endeavo bravo the cord fell naway his arm parted and floated upward the hand dimly see o each nside i the growing light he watched them with new interest a first none and the the othe pounced upo the noose at his neck they tore it naway and thrust it fiercely aside it undulation resembling those of nwate snake put it back put it back he thought he shouted these nwords to his hand fo the undoing of the noose had bee succeeded by nthe direst pang that he had yet experienced his neck ached horribly nhis brai wa o fire his heart which had bee fluttering faintly ngave great leap trying to force itself out at his mouth his whole nbody wa racked and wrenched with a insupportable anguish but his ndisobedient hand gave no heed to the command they beat the wate nvigorously with quick downward stroke forcing him to the surface he nfelt his head emerge his eye were blinded by the sunlight his chest nexpanded convulsively and with supreme and crowning agony his lung nengulfed great draught of ai which instantly he expelled i nshriek nhe wa now i full possessio of his physical sens they were indeed npreternaturally kee and alert something i the awful disturbance of nhis organic system had so exalted and refined them that they made record nof thing neve before perceived he felt the ripple upo his face and nheard thei separate sound a they struck he looked at the forest o nthe bank of the stream saw the individual tree the leaf and the nveining of each leaf saw the very insect upo them the locust the nbrilliant bodied fly the gray spider stretching thei web from twig nto twig he noted the prismatic color i all the dewdrop upo nmillio blade of grass the humming of the gnat that danced above the neddies of the stream the beating of the drago fly wing the nstrokes of the wate spider leg like oar which had lifted thei nboat all these made audible music fish slid along beneath his eye nand he heard the rush of it body parting the wate nhe had come to the surface facing dow the stream i moment the nvisible world seemed to wheel slowly round himself the pivotal point nand he saw the bridge the fort the soldier upo the bridge the ncaptai the sergeant the two private his executioner they were i nsilhouette against the blue sky they shouted and gesticulated pointing nat him the captai had draw his pistol but did not fire the others nwere unarmed thei movement were grotesque and horrible thei form ngigantic nsuddenly he heard sharp report and something struck the wate smartly nwithi few inch of his head spattering his face with spray he nheard second report and saw one of the sentinel with his rifle at nhis shoulde light cloud of blue smoke rising from the muzzle the nma i the wate saw the eye of the ma o the bridge gazing into his now through the sight of the rifle he observed that it wa gray eye nand remembered having read that gray eye were keenest and that all nfamous markme had them nevertheless this one had missed na counte swirl had caught farquha and turned him half round he wa nagai looking into the forest o the bank opposite the fort the sound nof clea high voice i monotonous singsong now rang out behind him nand came across the wate with distinctness that pierced and subdued nall othe sound eve the beating of the ripple i his ear although nno soldie he had frequented camp enough to know the dread nsignificance of that deliberate drawling aspirated chant the nlieutenant o shore wa taking part i the morning work how coldly nand pitilessly with what a eve calm intonatio presaging and nenforcing tranquillity i the me with what accurately measured nintervals fell those cruel word attentio company shoulde arm ready aim fire nfarquha dived dived a deeply a he could the wate roared i his nears like the voice of niagara yet he heard the dulled thunde of the nvolley and rising agai toward the surface met shining bit of metal nsingularly flattened oscillating slowly downward some of them touched nhim o the face and hand the fell away continuing thei descent one nlodged betwee his colla and neck it wa uncomfortably warm and he nsnatched it out na he rose to the surface gasping fo nfrom his enemy the sudde arrest of his motio the abrasio of one nof his hand o the gravel restored him and he wept with delight he ndug his finger into the sand threw it ove himself i handful and naudibly blessed it it looked like diamond ruby emerald he could nthink of nothing beautiful which it did not resemble the tree upo the nbank were giant garde plant he noted definite orde i thei narrangement inhaled the fragrance of thei bloom strange roseate nlight shone through the space among thei trunk and the wind made i nthei branch the music of xc3 xa6olia harp he had no wish to perfect his nescape wa content to remai i that enchanting spot until retake na whiz and rattle of grapeshot among the branch high above his head nroused him from his dream the baffled cannonee had fired him random nfarewell he sprang to his foot rushed up the sloping bank and plunged ninto the forest nall that day he traveled laying his course by the rounding su the nforest seemed interminable nowhere did he discove break i it not neve woodma road he had not know that he lived i so wild nregio there wa something uncanny i the revelatio nby nightfall he wa fatigued footsore famishing the thought of his nwife and childre urged him o at last he found road which led him i nwhat he knew to be the right directio it wa a wide and straight a ncity street yet it seemed untraveled no field bordered it no ndwelling anywhere not so much a the barking of dog suggested huma nhabitatio the black body of the tree formed straight wall o both nsides terminating o the horizo i point like diagram i lesso ni perspective ove head a he looked up through this rift i the nwood shone great golde star looking unfamilia and grouped i strange nconstellations he wa sure they were arranged i some orde which had nsecret and malig significance the wood o eithe side wa full of nsingula noise among which once twice and agai he distinctly nheard whisper i a unknow tongue nhis neck wa i pai and lifting relieved it feve by thrusting it nforward from betwee his teeth into the cold ai how softly the turf nhad carpeted the untraveled avenue he could no longe feel the roadway nbeneath his foot ndoubtless darkness and silence npeyto farquha wa dead his body with broke neck swung gently nfrom side to side beneath the timber of the owl creek bridge nchickamauga none sunny autum afternoo child strayed away from it rude home i nsmall field and entered forest unobserved it wa happy i new sense nof freedom from control happy i the opportunity of exploratio and nadventure fo this child spirit i body of it ancestor had fo nthousands of year bee trained to memorable feat of discovery and nconquest victory i battle whose critical moment were century nwhose victor camp were city of hew stone from the cradle of it nrace it had conquered it way through two continent and passing great nsea had penetrated third there to be bo to wa and dominio a nheritage nthe child wa boy aged about six year the so of poo plante i nhis younge manhood the fathe had bee soldie had fought against nnaked savage and followed the flag of his country into the capital of ncivilized race to the fa south i the peaceful life of plante the nwarrio fire survived once kindled it is neve extinguished the ma nloved military book and picture and the boy had understood enough to nmake himself woode sword though eve the eye of his fathe would nhardly have know it fo what it wa this weapo he now bore bravely na became the so of a heroic race and pausing now and agai i the nsunny space of the forest assumed with some exaggeratio the posture nof aggressio and defense that he had bee taught by the engrave art nmade reckless by the ease with which he overcame invisible foe nattempting to stay his advance he committed the commo enough military nerro of pushing the pursuit to dangerous extreme until he found nhimself upo the margi of wide but shallow brook whose rapid water nbarred his direct advance against the flying foe that had crossed with nillogical ease but the intrepid victo wa not to be baffled the nspirit of the race which had passed the great sea burned unconquerable ni that small breast and would not be denied finding place where some nbowlders i the bed of the stream lay but step o leap apart he nmade his way across and fell agai upo the rea guard of his imaginary nfoe putting all to the sword nnow that the battle had bee wo prudence required that he withdraw to nhis base of operation ala like many mightie conquero and like none the mightiest he could not curb the lust fo wa no lea that tempted fate will leave the loftiest sta nadvancing from the bank of the creek he suddenly found himself nconfronted with new and more formidable enemy i the path that he wa nfollowing sat bolt upright with ear erect and paw suspended before nit rabbit with startled cry the child turned and fled he knew not ni what directio calling with inarticulate cry fo his mothe nweeping stumbling his tende ski cruelly to by bramble his little nheart beating hard with terro breathless blind with tear lost i nthe forest the fo more tha a hou he wandered with erring foot nthrough the tangled undergrowth till at last overcome by fatigue he nlay dow i narrow space betwee two rock withi few yard of the nstream and still grasping his toy sword no longe weapo but ncompanio sobbed himself to sleep the wood bird sang merrily above nhis head the squirrel whisking thei bravery of tail ra barking nfrom tree to tree unconscious of the pity of it and somewhere fa away nwas strange muffled thunde a if the partridge were drumming i ncelebratio of nature victory ove the so of he immemorial nenslavers and back at the little plantatio where white me and black nwere hastily searching the field and hedge i alarm mothe heart nwas breaking fo he missing child nhours passed and the the little sleepe rose to his foot the chill of nthe evening wa i his limb the fea of the gloom i his heart but he nhad rested and he no longe wept with some blind instinct which nimpelled to actio he struggled through the undergrowth about him and ncame to more ope ground o his right the brook to the left ngentle acclivity studded with infrequent tree ove all the gathering ngloom of twilight thi ghostly mist rose along the wate it nfrightened and repelled him instead of recrossing i the directio nwhence he had come he turned his back upo it and went forward toward nthe dark inclosing wood suddenly he saw before him strange moving nobject which he took to be some large animal dog pig he could not nname it perhaps it wa bea he had see picture of bear but knew nof nothing to thei discredit and had vaguely wished to meet one but nsomething i form o movement of this object something i the nawkwardness of it approach told him that it wa not bea and ncuriosity wa stayed by fea he stood still and a it came slowly o ngained courage every moment fo he saw that at least it had not the nlong menacing ear of the rabbit possibly his impressionable mind wa nhalf conscious of something familia i it shambling awkward gait nbefore it had approached nea enough to resolve his doubt he saw that nit wa followed by anothe and anothe to right and to left were many nmore the whole ope space about him wa alive with them all moving ntoward the brook nthey were me they crept upo thei hand and knee they used thei nhands only dragging thei leg they used thei knee only thei arm nhanging idle at thei side they strove to rise to thei foot but fell nprone i the attempt they did nothing naturally and nothing alike nsave only to advance foot by foot i the same directio singly i npairs and i little group they came o through the gloom some halting nnow and agai while others crept slowly past them the resuming thei nmovement they came by dozen and by hundred a fa o eithe hand a none could see i the deepening gloom they extended and the black wood nbehind them appeared to be inexhaustible the very ground seemed i nmotio toward the creek occasionally one who had paused did not agai ngo o but lay motionless he wa dead some pausing made strange ngestures with thei hand erected thei arm and lowered them agai nclasped thei head spread thei palm upward a me are sometimes nsee to do i public praye nnot all of this did the child note it is what would have bee noted by na elde observe he saw little but that these were me yet crept like nbabes being me they were not terrible though unfamiliarly clad he nmoved among them freely going from one to anothe and peering into nthei face with childish curiosity all thei face were singularly nwhite and many were streaked and gouted with red something i this nsomething too perhaps i thei grotesque attitude and movement nreminded him of the painted clow whom he had see last summe i the ncircus and he laughed a he watched them but o and eve o they ncrept these maimed and bleeding me a heedless a he of the dramatic ncontrast betwee his laughte and thei ow ghastly gravity to him it nwas merry spectacle he had see his fathe negro creep upo thei nhands and knee fo his amusement had ridde them so making believe nthey were his horse he now approached one of these crawling figure nfrom behind and with a agile movement mounted it astride the ma sank nupo his breast recovered flung the small boy fiercely to the ground na a unbroke colt might have done the turned upo him face that nlacked lowe jaw from the uppe teeth to the throat wa great red ngap fringed with hanging shred of flesh and splinter of bone the nunnatural prominence of nose the absence of chi the fierce eye gave nthis ma the appearance of great bird of prey crimsoned i throat and nbreast by the blood of it quarry the ma rose to his knee the child nto his foot the ma shook his fist at the child the child terrified nat last ra to tree nea by got upo the farthe side of it and took na more serious view of the situatio and so the clumsy multitude ndragged itself slowly and painfully along i hideous pantomime moved nforward dow the slope like swarm of great black beetle with neve nsound of going i silence profound absolute ninstead of darkening the haunted landscape bega to brighte through nthe belt of tree beyond the brook shone strange red light the trunk nand branch of the tree making black lacework against it it struck nthe creeping figure and gave them monstrous shadow which caricatured nthei movement o the lit grass it fell upo thei face touching nthei whiteness with ruddy tinge accentuating the stain with which nso many of them were freaked and maculated it sparkled o button and nbits of metal i thei clothing instinctively the child turned toward nthe growing splendo and moved dow the slope with his horrible ncompanions i few moment had passed the foremost of the throng not nmuch of feat considering his advantage he placed himself i the nlead his woode sword still i hand and solemnly directed the march nconforming his pace to theirs and occasionally turning a if to see that nhis force did not straggle surely such leade neve before had such na following nscattered about upo the ground now slowly narrowing by the encroachment nof this awful march to wate were certai article to which i the nleade mind were coupled no significant association a occasional nblanket tightly rolled lengthwise doubled and the end bound togethe nwith string heavy knapsack here and there broke rifle such nthings i short a are found i the rea of retreating troop the spoo of me flying from thei hunter everywhere nea the creek nwhich here had margi of lowland the earth wa trodde into mud by nthe foot of me and horse a observe of bette experience i the use nof his eye would have noticed that these footprint pointed i both ndirections the ground had bee twice passed ove i advance and i nretreat few hour before these desperate stricke me with thei nmore fortunate and now distant comrade had penetrated the forest i nthousands thei successive battalion breaking into swarm and nre forming i line had passed the child o every side had almost ntrodde o him a he slept the rustle and murmu of thei march had not nawakened him almost withi stone throw of where he lay they had nfought battle but all unheard by him were the roa of the musketry nthe shock of the canno the thunde of the captain and the shouting nhe had slept through it all grasping his little woode sword with nperhaps tighte clutch i unconscious sympathy with his martial nenvironment but a heedless of the grandeu of the struggle a the dead nwho had died to make the glory nthe fire beyond the belt of wood o the farthe side of the creek nreflected to earth from the canopy of it ow smoke wa now suffusing nthe whole landscape it transformed the sinuous line of mist to the nvapo of gold the wate gleamed with dash of red and red too were nmany of the stone protruding above the surface but that wa blood the nless desperately wounded had stained them i crossing o them too the nchild now crossed with eage step he wa going to the fire a he nstood upo the farthe bank he turned about to look at the companion of nhis march the advance wa arriving at the creek the stronge had nalready draw themselves to the brink and plunged thei face into the nflood three o fou who lay without motio appeared to have no head nat this the child eye expanded with wonde eve his hospitable nunderstanding could not accept phenomeno implying such vitality a nthat afte slaking thei thirst these me had not had the strength to nback away from the wate no to keep thei head above it they were ndrowned i rea of these the ope space of the forest showed the nleade a many formless figure of his grim command a at first but not nnearly so many were i motio he waved his cap fo thei encouragement nand smilingly pointed with his weapo i the directio of the guiding nlight pilla of fire to this strange exodus nconfident of the fidelity of his force he now entered the belt of nwoods passed through it easily i the red illuminatio climbed nfence ra across field turning now and agai to coquet with his nresponsive shadow and so approached the blazing rui of dwelling ndesolatio everywhere i all the wide glare not living thing wa nvisible he cared nothing fo that the spectacle pleased and he danced nwith glee i imitatio of the wavering flame he ra about collecting nfuel but every object that he found wa too heavy fo him to cast i nfrom the distance to which the heat limited his approach i despai he nflung i his sword surrende to the superio force of nature his nmilitary caree wa at a end nshifting his positio his eye fell upo some outbuilding which had a noddly familia appearance a if he had dreamed of them he stood nconsidering them with wonde whe suddenly the entire plantatio with nit inclosing forest seemed to tu a if upo pivot his little nworld swung half around the point of the compass were reversed he nrecognized the blazing building a his ow home nfo nuttered series of inarticulate and indescribable cry something nbetwee the chattering of a ape and the gobbling of turkey nstartling soulless unholy sound the language of devil the child nwas deaf advantage this morning at daybreak the nenemy wa gone we have moved forward across his earthwork across nwhich we have so ofte vainly attempted to move before through the ndebris of his abandoned camp his staff and escort he is nfacing the distant crest holding his field glass against his eye with nboth hand his elbow needlessly elevated it is fashio it seems to ndignify the act we are all addicted to it suddenly he lower the glass nand say few word to those about him two o three aide detach nthemselves from the group and cante away into the wood along the nlines i each directio we did not hea his word but we know them tell general to send forward the skirmish line those of u who nhave bee out of place resume ou position the me resting at ease nstraighte themselves and the rank are re nsearing crept o taking advantage of every accident of ground and ngrowth to give himself bette cove his eye penetrated everywhere his nears took note of every sound he stilled his breathing and at nto assure himself beyond doubt before going back to report upo so nimportant matte searing pushed forward across the line of abandoned npits running from cove to cove i the more ope forest his eye nvigilant to discove possible straggler he came to the edge of nplantatio one of those forlo deserted homestead of the last year nof the wa upgrow with bramble ugly with broke fence and desolate nwith small structure which stood apart from the othe farm building o na slight elevatio this he thought would enable him to overlook large nscope of country i the directio that he supposed the enemy to have ntake i withdrawing this building which had originally consisted of nsingle room elevated upo fou post about te foot high wa now little nmore tha roof the floo had falle away the joist and plank nloosely piled o the ground below o resting o end at various angle nnot wholly to from thei fastening above the supporting post were nthemselves no longe vertical it looked a if the whole edifice would ngo dow at the touch of finge nconcealing himself i the debris of joist and flooring searing looked nacross the ope ground betwee his point of view and spu of kennesaw nmountai half mile away it wa his duty nto retu to his ow command with all possible speed and report his ndiscovery but the gray colum of confederate toiling up the mountai nroad wa singularly tempting his rifle a ordinary springfield but nfitted with globe sight and hai trigge would easily send it ounce nand quarte of lead hissing into thei midst that would probably not naffect the duratio and result of the wa but it is the business of nsoldie to kill it is also his habit if he is good soldie searing ncocked his rifle and set the trigge nbut it wa decreed from the beginning of time that private searing wa nnot to murde anybody that bright summe morning no wa the nconfederate retreat to be announced by him fo countless age event nhad bee so matching themselves togethe i that wondrous mosaic to some nparts of which dimly discernible we give the name of history that the nacts which he had i will would have marred the harmony of the patte nsome twenty five year previously the powe charged with the executio nof the work according to the desig had provided against that mischance nby causing the birth of certai male child i little village at the nfoot of the carpathia mountain had carefully reared it supervised nit educatio directed it desire into military channel and i due ntime made it a office of artillery by the concurrence of a infinite nnumbe of favoring influence and thei preponderance ove a infinite nnumbe of opposing one this office of artillery had bee made to ncommit breach of discipline and flee from his native country to avoid npunishment he had bee directed to new orleans instead of new york nwhere recruiting office awaited him o the wharf he wa enlisted and npromoted and thing were so ordered that he now commanded confederate nbattery some two mile along the line from where jerome searing the nfederal scout stood cocking his rifle nothing had bee neglected at nevery step i the progress of both these me life and i the life nof thei contemporary and ancestor and i the life of the ncontemporaries of thei ancestor the right thing had bee done to nbring about the desired result had anything i all this vast nconcatenatio bee overlooked private searing might have fired o the nretreating confederate that morning and would perhaps have missed a nit fell out confederate captai of artillery having nothing bette nto do while awaiting his tu to pull out and be off amused himself by nsighting field piece obliquely to his right at what he mistook fo nsome federal officer o the crest of hill and discharged it the nshot flew high of it mark na jerome searing drew back the hamme of his rifle and with his eye nupo the distant confederate considered where he could plant his shot nwith the best hope of making widow o a orpha o childless nmothe perhaps all three fo private searing although he had nrepeatedly refused promotio wa not without certai kind of nambitio he heard rushing sound i the ai like that made by the nwings of great bird swooping dow upo it prey more quickly tha he ncould apprehend the gradatio it increased to hoarse and horrible nroa a the missile that made it sprang at him out of the sky striking nwith deafening impact one of the post supporting the confusio of ntimbers above him smashing it into matchwood and bringing dow the ncrazy edifice with loud clatte i cloud of blinding dust nwhe jerome searing recovered consciousness he did not at once nunderstand what had occurred it wa indeed some time before he opened nhis eye fo while he believed that he had died and bee buried and nhe tried to recall some portion of the burial service he thought that nhis wife wa kneeling upo his grave adding he weight to that of the nearth upo his breast the two of them widow and earth had crushed his ncoffi unless the childre should persuade he to go home he would not nmuch longe be able to breathe he felt sense of wrong cannot nspeak to he he thought the dead have no voice and if ope my neyes shall get them full of earth nhe opened his eye great expanse of blue sky rising from fringe of nthe top of tree i the foreground shutting out some of the tree nhigh du mound angula i outline and crossed by a intricate npatternless system of straight line the whole a immeasurable distance naway distance so inconceivably great that it fatigued him and he nclosed his eye the moment that he did so he wa conscious of a ninsufferable light sound wa i his ear like the low rhythmic nthunde of distant sea breaking i successive wave upo the beach nand out of this noise seeming part of it o possibly coming from nbeyond it and intermingled with it ceaseless undertone came the narticulate word jerome searing you are caught like rat i trap ni trap trap trap nsuddenly there fell great silence black darkness a infinite ntranquillity and jerome searing perfectly conscious of his rathood nand well assured of the trap that he wa i remembering all and nowise nalarmed agai opened his eye to reconnoitre to note the strength of nhis enemy to pla his defense nhe wa caught i reclining posture his back firmly supported by nsolid beam anothe lay across his breast but he had bee able to nshrink little away from it so that it no longe oppressed him though nit wa immovable brace joining it at a angle had wedged him against na pile of board o his left fastening the arm o that side his leg nslightly parted and straight along the ground were covered upward to nthe knee with mass of debris which towered above his narrow horizo nhis head wa a rigidly fixed a i vise he could move his eye his nchi no more only his right arm wa partly free you must help u out nof this he said to it but he could not get it from unde the heavy ntimbe athwart his chest no move it outward more tha six inch at nthe elbow nsearing wa not seriously injured no did he suffe pai smart rap no the head from flying fragment of the splintered post incurred nsimultaneously with the frightfully sudde shock to the nervous system nhad momentarily dazed him his term of unconsciousness including the nperiod of recovery during which he had had the strange fancy had nprobably not exceeded few second fo the dust of the wreck had not nwholly cleared away a he bega a intelligent survey of the situatio nwith his partly free right hand he now tried to get hold of the beam nthat lay across but not quite against his breast i no way could he ndo so he wa unable to depress the shoulde so a to push the elbow nbeyond that edge of the timbe which wa nearest his knee failing i nthat he could not raise the forearm and hand to grasp the beam the nbrace that made a angle with it downward and backward prevented him nfrom doing anything i that directio and betwee it and his body the nspace wa not half so wide a the length of his forearm obviously he ncould not get his hand unde the beam no ove it the hand could not ni fact touch it at all having demonstrated his inability he ndesisted and bega to think whethe he could reach any of the xc3 xa9bris npiled upo his leg ni surveying the mass with view to determining that point his nattentio wa arrested by what seemed to be ring of shining metal nimmediately i front of his eye it appeared to him at first to nsurround some perfectly black substance and it wa somewhat more tha nhalf inch i diamete it suddenly occurred to his mind that the nblackness wa simply shadow and that the ring wa i fact the muzzle of nhis rifle protruding from the pile of xc3 xa9bris he wa not long i nsatisfying himself that this wa so if it wa satisfactio by nclosing eithe eye he could look little way along the barrel to the npoint where it wa hidde by the rubbish that held it he could see the none side with the corresponding eye at apparently the same angle a nthe othe side with the othe eye looking with the right eye the nweapo seemed to be directed at point to the left of his head and n_vice versa _ he wa unable to see the uppe surface of the barrel but ncould see the unde surface of the stock at slight angle the piece nwas i fact aimed at the exact centre of his forehead ni the perceptio of this circumstance i the recollectio that just npreviously to the mischance of which this uncomfortable situatio wa nthe result he had cocked the rifle and set the trigge so that touch nwould discharge it private searing wa affected with feeling of nuneasiness but that wa a fa a possible from fea he wa brave nma somewhat familia with the aspect of rifle from that point of nview and of canno too and now he recalled with something like namusement a incident of his experience at the storming of missionary nridge where walking up to one of the enemy embrasure from which he nhad see heavy gu throw charge afte charge of grape among the nassailants he had thought fo moment that the piece had bee nwithdraw he could see nothing i the opening but braze circle what nthat wa he had understood just i time to step aside a it pitched nanothe peck of iro dow that swarming slope to face firearm is one nof the commonest incident i soldie life firearm too with nmalevolent eye blazing behind them that is what soldie is fo nstill private searing did not altogethe relish the situatio and nturned away his eye nafte groping aimless with his right hand fo time he made a nineffectual attempt to release his left the he tried to disengage his nhead the fixity of which wa the more annoying from his ignorance of nwhat held it next he tried to free his foot but while exerting the npowerful muscle of his leg fo that purpose it occurred to him that ndisturbance of the rubbish which held them might discharge the rifle nhow it could have endured what had already befalle it he could not nunderstand although memory assisted him with several instance i npoint one i particula he recalled i which i moment of mental nabstractio he had clubbed his rifle and beate out anothe gentlema nbrains observing afterward that the weapo which he had bee diligently nswinging by the muzzle wa loaded capped and at full cock knowledge nof which circumstance would doubtless have cheered his antagonist to nlonge endurance he had always smiled i recalling that blunde of his gree and salad day a soldie but now he did not smile he turned nhis eye agai to the muzzle of the rifle and fo moment fancied that nit had moved it seemed somewhat neare nagai he looked away the top of the distant tree beyond the bound of nthe plantatio interested him he had not before observed how light and nfeathery they were no how darkly blue the sky wa eve among thei nbranches where they somewhat paled it with thei gree above him it nappeared almost black it will be uncomfortably hot here he thought a the day advance wonde which way am looking njudging by such shadow a he could see he decided that his face wa ndue north he would at least not have the su i his eye and north nwell that wa toward his wife and childre bah he exclaimed aloud what have they to do with it nhe closed his eye a ca get out may a well go to sleep the nrebels are gone and some of ou fellow are sure to stray out here nforaging they ll find me nbut he did not sleep gradually he became sensible of pai i his nforehead dull ache hardly perceptible at first but growing more and nmore uncomfortable he opened his eye and it wa gone closed them and nit returned the devil he said irrelevantly and stared agai at the nsky he heard the singing of bird the strange metallic note of the nmeadow lark suggesting the clash of vibrant blade he fell into npleasant memory of his childhood played agai with his brothe and nsiste raced across the field shouting to alarm the sedentary lark nentered the sombre forest beyond and with timid step followed the faint npath to ghost rock standing at last with audible heart throb before nthe dead ma cave and seeking to penetrate it awful mystery fo the nfirst time he observed that the opening of the haunted cave wa nencircled by ring of metal the all else vanished and left him gazing ninto the barrel of his rifle a before but whereas before it had seemed nneare it now seemed a inconceivable distance away and all the more nsiniste fo that he cried out and startled by something i his ow nvoice the note of fea lied to himself i denial if do sing out ni may stay here till die nhe now made no furthe attempt to evade the menacing stare of the gu nbarrel if he turned away his eye a instant it wa to look fo nassistance although he could not see the ground o eithe side the nrui and he permitted them to retu obedient to the imperative nfascinatio if he closed them it wa from weariness and instantly the npoignant pai i his forehead the prophecy and menace of the bullet nforced him to reope them nthe tensio of nerve and brai wa too severe nature came to his relief nwith interval of unconsciousness reviving from one of these he became nsensible of sharp smarting pai i his right hand and whe he worked nhis finger togethe o rubbed his palm with them he could feel that nthey were wet and slippery he could not see the hand but he knew the nsensatio it wa running blood i his delirium he had beate it nagainst the jagged fragment of the wreck had clutched it full of nsplinters he resolved that he would meet his fate more manly he wa nplai commo soldie had no religio and not much philosophy he could nnot die like hero with great and wise last word eve if there had nbee some one to hea them but he could die game and he would but nif he could only know whe to expect the shot nsome rat which had probably inhabited the shed came sneaking and nscampering about one of them mounted the pile of xc3 xa9bris that held the nrifle anothe followed and anothe searing regarded them at first with nindifference the with friendly interest the a the thought flashed ninto his bewildered mind that they might touch the trigge of his rifle nhe cursed them and ordered them to go away it is no business of nyours he cried nthe creature went away they would retu late attack his face gnaw naway his nose cut his throat he knew that but he hoped by that time nto be dead nnothing could now unfix his gaze from the little ring of metal with it nblack interio the pai i his forehead wa fierce and incessant he nfelt it gradually penetrating the brai more and more deeply until at nlast it progress wa arrested by the wood at the back of his head it ngrew momentarily more insufferable he bega wantonly beating his nlacerated hand against the splinter agai to counteract that horrible nache it seemed to throb with slow regula recurrence each pulsatio nsharpe tha the preceding and sometimes he cried out thinking he felt nthe fatal bullet no thought of home of wife and childre of country nof glory the whole record of memory wa effaced the world had passed naway not vestige remained here i this confusio of timber and nboards is the sole universe here is immortality i time each pai a neverlasting life the throb tick off eternity njerome searing the ma of courage the formidable enemy the strong nresolute warrio wa a pale a ghost his jaw wa falle his eye nprotruded he trembled i every fibre cold sweat bathed his entire nbody he screamed with fea he wa not insane he wa terrified ni groping about with his to and bleeding hand he seized at last nstrip of board and pulling felt it give way it lay parallel with his nbody and by bending his elbow a much a the contracted space would npermit he could draw it few inch at time finally it wa naltogethe loosened from the wreckage covering his leg he could lift nit clea of the ground it whole length great hope came into his nmind perhaps he could work it upward that is to say backward fa nenough to lift the end and push aside the rifle o if that were too ntightly wedged so place the strip of board a to deflect the bullet nwith this object he passed it backward inch by inch hardly daring to nbreathe lest that act somehow defeat his intent and more tha eve nunable to remove his eye from the rifle which might perhaps now haste nto improve it waning opportunity something at least had bee gained ni the occupatio of his mind i this attempt at self defense he wa nless sensible of the pai i his head and had ceased to wince but he nwas still dreadfully frightened and his teeth rattled like castanets nthe strip of board ceased to move to the suasio of his hand he tugged nat it with all his strength changed the directio of it length all he ncould but it had met some extended obstructio behind him and the end ni front wa still too fa away to clea the pile of xc3 xa9bris and reach nthe muzzle of the gu it extended indeed nearly a fa a the trigge nguard which uncovered by the rubbish he could imperfectly see with nhis right eye he tried to break the strip with his hand but had no nleverage i his defeat all his terro returned augmented tenfold the nblack aperture of the rifle appeared to threate sharpe and more nimminent death i punishment of his rebellio the track of the bullet nthrough his head ached with a intense anguish he bega to tremble nagai nsuddenly he became composed his tremo subsided he clenched his teeth nand drew dow his eyebrow he had not exhausted his mean of defense nnew desig had shaped itself i his mind anothe pla of battle nraising the front end of the strip of board he carefully pushed it nforward through the wreckage at the side of the rifle until it pressed nagainst the trigge guard the he moved the end slowly outward until he ncould feel that it had cleared it the closing his eye thrust it nagainst the trigge with all his strength there wa no explosio the nrifle had bee discharged a it dropped from his hand whe the building nfell but it did it work nlieutenant adria searing i command of the picket guard o that part nof the line through which his brothe jerome had passed o his missio nsat with attentive ear i his breastwork behind the line not the nfaintest sound escaped him the cry of bird the barking of nsquirrel the noise of the wind among the pine all were anxiously nnoted by his overstrained sense suddenly directly i front of his nline he heard faint confused rumble like the clatte of falling nbuilding translated by distance the lieutenant mechanically looked at nhis watch if you find him if not continue the nadvance until directed to halt there is reaso to think that the enemy nhas retreated nthe lieutenant nodded and said nothing the othe office retired i nmoment the general picked him up nfrom some ohio regiment think none of u had previously know him nand it would have bee strange if we had fo no two of u came from the nsame state no eve from adjoining state the general seemed to think nthat positio o his staff wa distinctio that should be so njudiciously conferred a not to beget any sectional jealousy and nimperil the integrity of that part of the country which wa still a nintege he would not eve choose officer from his ow command but by nsome jugglery at department headquarters obtained them from othe nbrigades unde such circumstance ma service had to most officer are content to nbe le flamboyantly attired he wa very striking and conspicuous nfigure a to the rest he had gentlema manner schola head nand lio heart his age wa about thirty nwe all soo came to like brayle a much a we admired him and it wa nwith sincere conce that i the engagement at stone rive ou first nactio afte he joined u we observed that he had one most nobjectionable and matte ni every late engagement while brayle wa with u it wa the same way nhe would sit his horse like a equestria statue i storm of bullet nand grape i the most exposed place whereve i fact duty nrequiring him to go permitted him to remai whe without trouble and nwith distinct advantage to his reputatio fo commo sense he might nhave bee i such security a is possible o battlefield i the brief nintervals of personal inactio no foot from necessity o i deference to his dismounted commande o nassociates his conduct wa the same he would stand like rock i the nope whe officer and me alike had take to cove while me olde i nservice and year highe i rank and of unquestionable intrepidity nwere loyally preserving behind the crest of hill life infinitely nprecious to thei country this fellow would stand equally idle o the nridge facing i the directio of the sharpest fire nwhe battle are going o i ope ground it frequently occurs that the nopposing line confronting each othe withi stone throw fo hour nhug the earth a closely a if they loved it the line officer i thei nprope place flatte themselves no le and the field officer thei nhorses all killed o sent to the rea crouch beneath the infernal ncanopy of hissing lead and screaming iro without thought of personal ndignity ni such circumstance the life of staff office of brigade is ndistinctly not happy one mainly because of it precarious tenure nand the unnerving alternation of emotio to which he is exposed from npositio of that comparative security from which civilia would nascribe his escape to miracle he may be despatched with a orde to nsome commande of prone regiment i the front line perso fo the nmoment inconspicuous and not always easy to find without deal of nsearch among me somewhat preoccupied and i admiring marksme i returning well it is not customary to retu nbrayle practice wa different he would consig his horse to the care nof a orderly he loved his horse and walk quietly away o his nperilous errand with neve stoop of the back his splendid figure naccentuated by his uniform holding the eye with strange fascinatio nwe watched him with suspended breath ou heart i ou mouth o one noccasio of this kind indeed one of ou numbe a impetuous nstammere wa so possessed by his emotio that he shouted at me ll b bet you two d dollar they drop him b before he get nto that d ditch ni did not accept nea the right extremity of the arc colonel ward wa at the nleft the suggestio to leave the horse obviously enough meant that nbrayle wa to take the longe line through the wood and among the me nindeed were i crackling conflagratio stop that damned fool shouted the general na private of the escort with more ambitio tha brain spurred forward nto obey and withi te yard left himself and his horse dead o the nfield of hono nbrayle wa beyond recall galloping easily along parallel to the enemy nand le tha two hundred yard distant he wa picture to see his nhat had bee blow o shot from his head and his long blond hai rose nand fell with the motio of his horse he sat erect i the saddle nholding the rein lightly i his left hand his right hanging carelessly nat his side a occasional glimpse of his handsome profile a he turned nhis head one way o the othe proved that the interest which he took i nwhat wa going o wa natural and without affectatio nthe picture wa intensely dramatic but i no degree thei order nou fellow sprang to thei foot and swarming into the ope sent broad nsheets of bullet against the blazing crest of the offending work nwhich poured a answering fire into thei unprotected group with deadly neffect the artillery o both side joined the battle punctuating the nrattle and roa with deep earth shaking explosion and tearing the ai nwith storm of screaming grape which from the enemy side splintered nthe tree and spattered them with blood and from ours defiled the smoke nof his arm with bank and cloud of dust from his parapet nmy attentio had bee fo moment draw to the stood i the shot swept space nmotionless his face toward the enemy at some little distance lay his nhorse instantly saw what had stopped him na topographical enginee had early i the day made hasty nexaminatio of the ground and now remembered that at that point wa ndeep and sinuous gully crossing half the field from the enemy line nit general course at right angle to it from where we now were it wa ninvisible and brayle had evidently not know about it clearly it wa nimpassable it salient angle would have afforded him absolute security nif he had chose to be satisfied with the miracle already fell the nfiring ceased few desultory shot at long interval serving rathe to naccentuate tha break the silence it wa a if both side had suddenly nrepented of thei profitless crime fou stretche bearer commande i that nset immobile face wa no sig it wa a hard a bronze moment late nthe general rode away followed by his staff and escort the colonel nhumiliated and indignant wa about to orde captai coulte i arrest nwhe the latte spoke few word i low tone to his bugle saluted nand rode straight forward into the notch where presently at the nsummit of the road his field glass at his eye he showed against the nsky he and his horse sharply defined and statuesque the bugle had ndashed dow the speed and disappeared behind wood presently his bugle nwas heard singing i the cedar and i a incredibly short time nsingle gu with it caisso each draw by six horse and manned by it nfull complement of gunner came bounding and banging up the grade i nstorm of dust unlimbered unde cove and wa ru forward by hand to nthe fatal crest among the dead horse gesture of the captai arm nsome strangely agile movement of the me i loading and almost before nthe troop along the way had ceased to hea the rattle of the wheel ngreat white cloud sprang forward dow the slope and with deafening nreport the affai at coulte notch had begu nit is not intended to relate i detail the progress and incident of nthat ghastly contest contest without vicissitude it alternation nonly different degree of despai almost at the instant whe captai ncoulte gu blew it challenging cloud twelve answering cloud rolled nupward from among the tree about the plantatio house deep multiple nreport roared back like broke echo and thenceforth to the end the nfederal cannoneer fought thei hopeless battle i a atmosphere of nliving iro whose thought were lightning and whose deed were death nunwilling to see the effort which he could not aid and the slaughte nwhich he could not stay the colonel ascended the ridge at point nquarte of mile to the left whence the notch itself invisible but npushing up successive mass of smoke seemed the crate of volcano i nthundering eruptio with his glass he watched the enemy gun noting na he could the effect of coulte fire if coulte still lived to ndirect it he saw that the federal gunner ignoring those of the nenemy piece whose position could be determined by thei smoke only ngave thei whole attentio to the one that maintained it place i the nope the law i front of the house ove and about that hardy piece nthe shell exploded at interval of few second some exploded i the nhouse a could be see by thi ascension of smoke from the breached nroof figure of prostrate me and horse were plainly visible if ou fellow are doing so good work with single gu said the ncolonel to a aide who happened to be nearest they must be suffering nlike the devil from twelve go dow and present the commande of that npiece with my congratulation o the accuracy of his fire nturning to his adjutant general he said did you observe coulte ndamned reluctance to obey order yes si did well say nothing about it please do think the general will care nto make any accusation he will probably have enough to do i nexplaining his ow connectio with this uncommo way of amusing the nrea guard of retreating enemy na young office approached from below climbing breathless up the nacclivity almost before he had saluted he gasped out colonel am directed by colonel harmo to say that the enemy gun nare withi easy reach of ou rifle and most of them visible from nseveral point along the ridge nthe brigade commande looked at him without trace of interest i his nexpressio know it he said quietly nthe young adjutant wa visibly embarrassed colonel harmo would like nto have permissio to silence those gun he stammered so should the colonel said i the same tone present my ncompliments to colonel harmo and say to him that the general order nfo the infantry not to fire are still i force nthe adjutant saluted and retired the colonel ground his heel into the nearth and turned to look agai at the enemy gun colonel said the adjutant general do know that ought to say nanything but there is something wrong i all this do you happe to nknow that captai coulte is from the south no _was_ he indeed heard that last summe the divisio which the general the commanded nwas i the vicinity of coulte home camped there fo week and liste said the colonel interrupting with a upward gesture do you nhea _that_ that wa the silence of the federal gu the staff the orderly the nlines of infantry behind the crest all had heard and were looking ncuriously i the directio of the crate whence no smoke now ascended nexcept desultory cloudlets from the enemy shell the came the blare nof bugle faint rattle of wheel minute late the sharp report nrecommenced with double activity the demolished gu had bee replaced nwith sound one yes said the adjutant general resuming his narrative the general nmade the acquaintance of coulte family there wa trouble do nknow the exact nature of it something about coulte wife she is nred hot secessionist a they all are except coulte himself but she ni good wife and high bred lady there wa complaint to army nheadquarters the general wa transferred to this divisio it is odd nthat coulte battery should afterward have bee assigned to it nthe colonel had rise from the rock upo which they had bee sitting nhis eye were blazing with generous indignatio see here morriso said he looking his gossiping staff office nstraight i the face did you get that story from gentlema o nlia do want to say how got it colonel unless it is necessary he nwas blushing trifle but ll stake my life upo it truth i the nmai nthe colonel turned toward small knot of officer some distance away lieutenant williams he shouted none of the officer detached himself from the group and coming forward nsaluted saying pardo me colonel thought you had bee informed nwilliams is dead dow there by the gu what ca do si nlieutenant williams wa the aide who had had the pleasure of conveying nto the office i charge of the gu his brigade commande ncongratulations go said the colonel and direct the withdrawal of that gu ninstantly no ll go myself nhe strode dow the declivity toward the rea of the notch at nbreak neck pace ove rock and through bramble followed by his little nretinue i tumultuous disorde at the foot of the declivity they nmounted thei waiting animal and took to the road at lively trot nround bend and into the notch the spectacle which they encountered nthere wa appalling nwithi that defile barely broad enough fo single gu were piled the nwrecks of no fewe tha fou they had noted the silencing of only the nlast one disabled there had bee lack of me to replace it quickly nwith anothe the xc3 xa9bris lay o both side of the road the me had nmanaged to keep a ope way betwee through which the fifth piece wa nnow firing the me they looked like demon of the pit all were nhatless all stripped to the waist thei reeking skin black with nblotches of powde and spattered with gout of blood they worked like nmadme with ramme and cartridge leve and lanyard they set thei nswolle shoulder and bleeding hand against the wheel at each recoil nand heaved the heavy gu back to it place there were no command i nthat awful environment of whooping shot exploding shell shrieking nfragments of iro and flying splinter of wood none could have bee nheard officer if officer there were were indistinguishable all nworked togethe each while he lasted governed by the eye whe the gu nwas sponged it wa loaded whe loaded aimed and fired the colonel nobserved something new to his military experience something horrible nand unnatural the gu wa bleeding at the mouth i temporary default nof wate the ma sponging had dipped his sponge into pool of ncomrade blood i all this work there wa no clashing the duty of the ninstant wa obvious whe one fell anothe looking trifle cleane nseemed to rise from the earth i the dead ma track to fall i his ntu nwith the ruined gun lay the ruined me alongside the wreckage unde nit and atop of it and back dow the road ghastly processio crept no hand and knee such of the wounded a were able to move the ncolonel he had compassionately sent his cavalcade to the right about nhad to ride ove those who were entirely dead i orde not to crush nthose who were partly alive into that hell he tranquilly held his way nrode up alongside the gu and i the obscurity of the last discharge ntapped upo the cheek the ma holding the ramme who straightway fell nthinking himself killed fiend seve time damned sprang out of the nsmoke to take his place but paused and gazed up at the mounted office nwith a unearthly regard his teeth flashing betwee his black lip his neyes fierce and expanded burning like coal beneath his bloody brow nthe colonel made a authoritative gesture and pointed to the rea the nfiend bowed i toke of obedience it wa captai coulte nsimultaneously with the colonel arresting sig silence fell upo the nwhole field of actio the processio of missile no longe streamed ninto that defile of death fo the enemy also had while the trench were dug to receive them nsome found at too great distance from these rallying point were nburied where they lay there wa little attempt at identificatio nthough i most case the presumably follow one nof the retiring burial squad nwhe all were gone he walked straight away into the forest toward the nred west it light staining his face like blood the ai of confidence nwith which he now strode along showed that he wa o familia ground he nhad recovered his bearing the dead o his right and o his left were nunregarded a he passed a occasional low moa from some nsorely stricke wretch whom the relief party had not reached and who nwould have to pas comfortless night beneath the star with his thirst nto keep him company wa equally unheeded what indeed could the noffice have done being no surgeo and having no wate nat the head of shallow ravine mere depressio of the ground lay nsmall group of body he saw and swerving suddenly from his course nwalked rapidly toward them scanning each one sharply a he passed he nstopped at last above one which lay at slight remove from the others nnea clump of small tree he looked at it narrowly it seemed to nsti he stooped and laid his hand upo it face it screamed nthe office wa captai downing madwell of massachusetts regiment of ninfantry daring and intelligent soldie a honorable ma ni the regiment were two brother named halcrow caffal and creede nhalcrow caffal halcrow wa sergeant i captai madwell company and nthese two me the sergeant and the captai were devoted friend i so nfa a disparity of rank step upward i rank but betwee nthe highest no commissioned and the lowest commissioned office the ngulf is deep and wide and the old relatio wa maintained with ndifficulty and difference ncreede animosity but fo the restraining influence of thei mutual nrelatio to caffal these two patriot would doubtless have endeavored to ndeprive thei country of each othe service nat the opening of the and have long held the opinio that it would be nbette if you were dead nthe art of repartee wa cultivated i military circle a early a 1862 na half hou late captai madwell company wa drive from it mile away nthe captai wa now standing at the side of his subordinate and friend nsergeant halcrow wa mortally hurt his clothing wa deranged it seemed nto have bee violently to apart exposing the loop nof small intestine i all his experience captai madwell had not see nwound like this he could neithe conjecture how it wa made no explai nthe attendant circumstance the strangely to clothing the of na low thinly wooded hill he saw several dark object moving about namong the falle me herd of swine one stood with it back to him nit shoulder sharply elevated it forefoot were upo huma body it nhead wa depressed and invisible the bristly ridge of it chine showed nblack against the red west captai madwell drew away his eye and fixed nthem agai upo the thing which had bee his friend nthe ma who had suffered these monstrous mutilation wa alive at nintervals he moved his limb he moaned at every breath he stared nblankly into the face of his friend and if touched screamed i his ngiant agony he had to up the ground o which he lay his clenched nhands were full of leaf and twig and earth articulate speech wa nbeyond his powe it wa impossible to know if he were sensible to nanything but pai prometheus wa imploring neverything all the whole no ego fo the boo of oblivio to the nearth and the sky alike to the tree to the ma to whateve took form ni sense o consciousness this incarnate turned away struck his hand upo his forehead and nstrode from the spot the swine catching sight of him threw up thei ncrimso muzzle regarding him suspiciously second and the with ngruff concerted grunt raced away out of sight horse it foreleg nsplintered by canno shot lifted it head sidewise from the ground nand neighed piteously madwell stepped forward drew his revolve and nshot the poo beast betwee the eye narrowly observing it ndeath struggle which contrary to his expectatio wa violent and nlong but at last it lay still the tense muscle of it lip which had nuncovered the teeth i horrible gri relaxed the sharp clea cut nprofile took o look of profound peace and rest nalong the distant thinly wooded crest to westward the fringe of sunset nfire had now nearly burned itself out the light upo the trunk of the ntrees had faded to tende gray shadow were i thei top like great ndark bird aperch night wa coming and there were mile of haunted nforest betwee captai madwell and camp yet he blood ncaptai madwell rose to his foot and drew his sword from the scabbard nhe passed the finger of his left hand along the edge from hilt to npoint he held it out straight before him a if to test his nerve nthere wa no visible tremo of the blade the ray of bleak skylight that nit reflected wa steady and true he stooped and with his left hand tore naway the dying ma shirt rose and placed the point of the sword just nove the heart this time he did not withdraw his eye grasping the nhilt with both hand he thrust downward with all his strength and nweight the blade sank into the ma body through his body into the nearth captai madwell came nea falling forward upo his work the ndying ma drew up his knee and at the same time threw his right arm nacross his breast and grasped the steel and rope nthe general finished writing folded the half sheet of pape and spoke nto the soldie guarding adderso here tassma take that to the nadjutant general the retu and the prisone general said the serious matte how ca know that have neve bee dead i all my life have nheard that death is serious matte but neve from any of those who nhave experienced it nthe general wa silent fo moment the ma interested perhaps amused nhim type not previously encountered death he said is at least loss loss of such happiness a we nhave and of opportunity fo more loss of which we shall neve be conscious ca be borne with composure nand therefore expected without apprehensio you must have observed ngeneral that of all the dead me with whom it is you soldierly npleasure to strew you path none show sign of regret if the being dead is not regrettable conditio yet the becoming so nthe act of dying appears to be distinctly disagreeable to one who ha nnot lost the powe to feel pai is disagreeable no doubt neve suffe it without more o le ndiscomfort but he who life longest is most exposed to it what you ncall dying is simply the last pai there is really no such thing a ndying suppose fo illustratio that attempt to escape you lift the nrevolve that you are courteously concealing i you lap and nthe general blushed like girl the laughed softly disclosing his nbrilliant teeth made slight inclinatio of his handsome head and said nnothing the spy continued you fire and have i my stomach what ndid not swallow fall but am not dead afte half hou of agony nam dead but at any give instant of that half hou wa eithe alive no dead there is no transitio period whe am hanged to morrow morning it will be quite the same while nconscious shall be living whe dead unconscious nature appears to nhave ordered the matte quite i my interest the way that should have nordered it myself it is so simple he added with smile that it nseems hardly worth while to be hanged at all nat the finish of his remark there wa long silence the general sat nimpassive looking into the ma face but apparently not attentive to nwhat had bee said it wa a if his eye had mounted guard ove the nprisone while his mind concerned itself with othe matter presently nhe drew long deep breath shuddered a one awakened from dreadful ndream and exclaimed almost inaudibly death is horrible this ma of ndeath it wa horrible to ou savage ancestor said the spy gravely because they had not enough intelligence to dissociate the idea of nconsciousness from the idea of the physical form i which it is nmanifested a a eve lowe orde of intelligence that of the monkey nfo example may be unable to imagine house without inhabitant and nseeing ruined hut fancy suffering occupant to u it is horrible nbecause we have inherited the tendency to think it so accounting fo nthe notio by wild and fanciful theory of anothe world a name of nplaces give rise to legend explaining them and reasonless conduct to nphilosophies i justificatio you ca hang me general but there you npowe of evil end you cannot condem me to heave nthe general appeared not to have heard the spy talk had merely turned nhis thought into a unfamilia channel but there they pursued thei nwill independently to conclusion of thei ow the storm had ceased nand something of the solem spirit of the night had imparted itself to nhis reflection giving them the sombre tinge of supernatural dread nperhaps there wa a element of prescience i it should not like to ndie he said not to night nhe wa interrupted if indeed he had intended to speak furthe by the nentrance of a office of his staff captai hasterlick the nprovost marshal this recalled him to himself the absent look passed naway from his face captai he said acknowledging the office salute this ma is nyankee spy captured inside ou line with incriminating paper o him nhe ha confessed how is the weathe the storm is ove si and the moo shining good take file of me conduct him at once to the parade ground and nshoot him na sharp cry broke from the spy lip he threw himself forward thrust nout his neck expanded his eye clenched his hand good god he cried hoarsely almost inarticulately you do not mea nthat you forget am not to die until morning have said nothing of morning replied the general coldly that wa na assumptio of you ow you die now but general beg implore you to remembe am to hang it will ntake some time to erect the gallows two hour a hou spy are nhanged have right unde military law fo heave sake general nconside how short captai observe my direction nthe office drew his sword and fixing his eye upo the prisone pointed nsilently to the opening of the tent the prisone hesitated the office ngrasped him by the colla and pushed him gently forward a he napproached the tent pole the frantic ma sprang to it and with cat like nagility seized the handle of the bowie knife plucked the weapo from nthe scabbard and thrusting the captai aside leaped upo the general nwith the fury of madma hurling him to the ground and falling nheadlong upo him a he lay the table wa overturned the candle nextinguished and they fought blindly i the darkness the nprovost marshal sprang to the assistance of his superio office and wa nhimself prostrated upo the struggling form curse and inarticulate ncries of rage and pai came from the welte of limb and body the ntent came dow upo them and beneath it hampering and enveloping fold nthe struggle went o private tassma returning from his errand and ndimly conjecturing the situatio threw dow his rifle and laying hold nof the flouncing canvas at random vainly tried to drag it off the me nunde it and the sentinel who paced up and dow i front not daring to nleave his beat though the sky should fall discharged his rifle the nreport alarmed the camp drum beat the long roll and bugle sounded the nassembly bringing swarm of half clad me into the moonlight dressing na they ra and falling into line at the sharp command of thei nofficers this wa well being i line the me were unde control they nstood at arm while the general staff and the me of his escort nbrought orde out of confusio by lifting off the falle tent and npulling apart the breathless and bleeding actor i that strange ncontentio nbreathless indeed wa one the captai wa dead the handle of the nbowie knife protruding from his throat wa pressed back beneath his nchi until the end had caught i the angle of the jaw and the hand that ndelivered the blow had bee unable to remove the weapo i the dead nma hand wa his sword clenched with grip that defied the strength nof the living it blade wa streaked with red to the hilt nlifted to his foot the general sank back to the earth with moa and nfainted besides his bruise he had two sword thrust one through the nthigh the othe through the shoulde nthe spy had suffered the least damage apart from broke right arm nhis wound were such only a might have bee incurred i a ordinary ncombat with nature weapon but he wa dazed and seemed hardly to know nwhat had occurred he shrank away from those attending him cowered upo nthe ground and uttered unintelligible remonstrance his face swolle nby blow and stained with gout of blood nevertheless showed white nbeneath his disheveled hai a white a that of corpse the ma is not insane said the surgeo preparing bandage and nreplying to questio he is suffering from fright who and what is nhe nprivate tassma bega to explai it wa the opportunity of his life he nomitted nothing that could i any way accentuate the importance of his now relatio to the night event whe he had finished his story and nwas ready to begi it agai nobody gave him any attentio nthe general had now recovered consciousness he raised himself upo his nelbow looked about him and seeing the spy crouching by camp fire nguarded said simply take that ma to the parade ground and shoot him the general mind wanders said a office standing nea his mind doe _not_ wande the adjutant general said have nmemorandum from him about this business he had give that same orde to nhasterlick with motio of the hand toward the dead provost marshal and by god it shall be executed nte minute late sergeant parke adderso of the federal army nphilosophe and wit kneeling i the moonlight and begging incoherently nfo his life wa shot to death by twenty me a the volley rang out nupo the kee ai of the midnight general clavering lying white and nstill i the red glow of the camp fire opened his big blue eye looked npleasantly upo those about him and said how silent it all is nthe surgeo looked at the adjutant general gravely and significantly nthe patient eye slowly closed and thus he lay fo few moment nthe his face suffused with smile of ineffable sweetness he said nfaintly suppose this must be death and so passed away na affai of outpost ni nconcerning the wish to be dead ntwo me sat i conversatio one wa the governo of the state the yea nwas 1861 the wa wa o and the governo already famous fo the nintelligence and zeal with which he directed all the power and nresources of his state to the service of the unio what _you_ the governo wa saying i evident surprise you too nwant military commissio really the fifing and drumming must have neffected profound alteratio i you conviction i my characte of nrecruiting sergeant suppose ought not to be fastidious but there nwas touch of irony i his manne well have you forgotte that a noath of allegiance is required have altered neithe my conviction no my sympathy said the nothe tranquilly while my sympathy are with the south a you do me nthe hono to recollect have neve doubted that the north wa i the nright am southerne i fact and i feeling but it is my habit i nmatters of importance to act a think not a feel nthe governo wa absently tapping his desk with pencil he did not nimmediately reply afte while he said have heard that there are nall kind of me i the world so suppose there are some like that nand doubtless you think yourself one ve know you long time and npardo me do think so the am to understand that my applicatio is denied unless you ca remove my belief that you southe sympathy are i nsome degree disqualificatio yes do not doubt you good faith and ni know you to be abundantly fitted by intelligence and special training nfo the duty of a office you conviction you say favo the unio ncause but prefe ma with his heart i it the heart is what me nfight with look here governo said the younge ma with smile that had more nlight tha warmth have something up my sleeve qualificatio which ni had hoped it would not be necessary to mentio great military nauthority ha give simple recipe fo being good soldie try nalways to get yourself killed it is with that purpose that wish to nente the service am not perhaps much of patriot but wish to nbe dead nthe governo looked at him rathe sharply the little coldly there ni simple and franke way he said i my family si wa the reply we do not do that no armisted ha neve done that na long day of battle at pittsburg landing had nsullenly retired to corinth whence he had come fo manifest nincompetence grant whose beate army had bee saved from destructio nand capture by buell soldierly were already struck and dow few wounded me ncame limping awkwardly out of the undergrowth from the skirmish line i nfront most of them did not pause but held thei way with white face nand set teeth to nseeming to float above it like the melody of soaring bird rang the nslow aspirated monotone of the captai several command without nemphasis without accent musical and restful a a evensong unde the nharvest moo familia with this tranquilizing chant i moment of nimminent peril these raw soldier of le tha yea training nyielded themselves to the spell executing it mandate with the ncomposure and
