the skirmisher unde order to rally o the nreserve came out of the wood like hunted hare and formed o the left nof the stiff little line breathing hard and thankful fo the boo of nbreath niii nthe fighting of one whose heart wa not i the quarrel nguided i his retreat by that of the fugitive wounded the governo nstruggled bravely to the rea through the bad bit of jungle he wa nwell winded and trifle confused excepting single rifle shot now and nagai there wa no sound of strife behind him the enemy wa pulling nhimself togethe fo new onset against a antagonist of whose number nand tactical dispositio he wa i doubt the fugitive felt that he nwould probably be spared to his country and only commended the narrangements of providence to that end but i leaping small brook i nmore ope ground one of the arrangement incurred the mischance of ndisabling sprai at the ankle he wa unable to continue his flight fo nhe wa too fat to hop and afte several vai attempt causing nintolerable pai seated himself o the earth to nurse his ignoble ndisability and deprecate the military situatio na brisk renewal of the firing broke out and stray bullet came flitting nand droning by the came the crash of two clea definite volley nfollowed by continuous rattle through which he heard the yell and ncheers of the combatant punctuated by thunderclap of canno all this ntold him that armisted little command wa bitterly beset and fighting nat close quarter the wounded me whom he had distanced bega to nstraggle by o eithe hand thei number visibly augmented by new nlevies from the line singly and by two and three some supporting ncomrades more desperately hurt tha themselves but all deaf to his nappeals fo assistance they sifted through the underbrush and ndisappeared the firing wa increasingly loude and more distinct and npresently the ailing fugitive were succeeded by me who strode with nfirme tread occasionally facing about and discharging thei piece nthe doggedly resuming thei retreat reloading a they walked two o nthree fell a he looked and lay motionless one had enough of life left ni him to make pitiful attempt to drag himself to cove passing ncomrade paused beside him long enough to fire appraised the poo ndevil disability with look and moved sullenly o inserting ncartridge i his weapo ni all this wa none of the pomp of wa no hint of glory eve i his ndistress and peril the helpless civilia could not forbea to contrast nit with the gorgeous parade and review held i hono of himself with nthe brilliant uniform the music the banner and the marching it wa na ugly and sickening afte making to the various visible nforms of nature solem promise to be damned that gentlema resumed nthe ai of stolidity which is supposed to be appropriate to state of nalert military attentio nii ncaptai hartroy held a independent command his force consisted of ncompany of infantry squadro of cavalry and sectio of artillery ndetached from the army to which they belonged to defend a important ndefile i the cumberland mountain i tennessee it wa field noffice command held by line office promoted from the rank where nhe had quietly served until discovered his post wa one of nexceptional peril it defense entailed heavy responsibility and he nhad wisely bee give corresponding discretionary power all the more nnecessary because of his distance from the mai army the precarious nnature of his communication and the lawless characte of the enemy nirregula troop infesting that regio he had strongly fortified his nlittle camp which embraced village of half doze dwelling and ncountry store and had collected considerable quantity of supply to na few resident civilian of know loyalty with whom it wa desirable to ntrade and of whose service i various way he sometimes availed nhimself he had give writte pass admitting them withi his line it ni easy to understand that a abuse of this privilege i the interest of nthe enemy might entail serious consequence captai hartroy had made a norde to the effect that any one so abusing it would be summarily shot nwhile the sentinel had bee examining the civilia pas the captai nhad eyed the latte narrowly he thought his appearance familia and had nat first no doubt of having give him the pas which had satisfied the nsentinel it wa not until the ma had got out of sight and hearing that nhis identity wa disclosed by revealing light from memory with nsoldierly promptness of decisio the office had acted o the nrevelatio niii nto any but singularly self possessed ma the apparitio of a office nof the military force formidably clad bearing i one no othe neffect tha somewhat to intensify his tranquillity he might easily nenough have escaped into the forest to the right o the left but chose nanothe course of actio turned and quietly faced the to observe the slight pallo of the ncivilia face at these word and the only othe manifestatio nattesting thei significance wa voluntary relaxatio of the thumb and nfingers holding the dishonored pape which falling to the road nunheeded wa rolled by gentle wind and the lay still with coating nof dust a i humiliatio fo the lie that it bore moment late the ncivilia still looking unmoved into the barrel of the pistol said yes am drame brune confederate spy and you prisone have o nmy perso a you will soo discove pla of you fort and it narmament statement of the distributio of you me and thei numbe na map of the approach showing the position of all you outpost my nlife is fairly yours but if you wish it take i more formal way tha nby you ow hand and if you are willing to spare me the indignity of nmarching into camp at the muzzle of you pistol promise you that nwill neithe resist escape no remonstrate but will submit to nwhateve penalty may be imposed nthe office lowered his pistol uncocked it and thrust it into it nplace i his belt brune advanced step extending his right hand it is the hand of traito and spy said the office coldly and ndid not take it the othe bowed come said the captai let u go to camp you shall not die until nto morrow morning nhe turned his back upo his prisone and these two enigmatical me nretraced thei step and soo passed the sentinel who expressed his ngeneral sense of thing by needle and exaggerated salute to his ncommande niv nearly o the morning afte these event the two me capto and captive nsat i the tent of the forme table wa betwee them o which lay namong numbe of letter official and private which the captai had nwritte during the night the incriminating paper found upo the spy nthat gentlema had slept through the night i a adjoining tent nunguarded both having breakfasted were now smoking m brune said captai hartroy you probably do not understand why nrecognized you i you disguise no how wa aware of you name have not sought to lea captai the prisone said with quiet ndignity nevertheless should like you to know if the story will not offend nyou will perceive that my knowledge of you go back to the autum of n1861 at that time you were private i a ohio regiment brave and ntrusted soldie to the surprise and grief of you officer and comrade nyou deserted and went ove to the enemy soo afterward you were ncaptured i skirmish recognized tried by court martial and sentenced nto be shot awaiting the executio of the sentence you were confined nunfettered i freight ca standing o side track of railway at grafto virginia said brune pushing the ash from his ciga nwith the little finge of the hand holding it and without looking up at grafto virginia the captai repeated one dark and stormy night na soldie who had just returned from long fatiguing march wa put o nguard ove you he sat o cracke box inside the ca nea the doo nhis rifle loaded and the bayonet fixed you sat i corne and his norders were to kill you if you attempted to rise but if _asked_ to rise he might call the corporal of the guard yes a the long silent hour wore away the soldie yielded to the ndemands of nature he himself incurred the death penalty by sleeping at nhis post of duty you did what you recognize me you have know me all along nthe captai had rise and wa walking the floo of his tent visibly nexcited his face wa flushed the gray eye had lost the cold pitiless nlook which they had show whe brune had see them ove the pistol nbarrel they had softened wonderfully knew you said the spy with his customary tranquillity the moment nyou faced me demanding my surrende i the circumstance it would have nbee hardly becoming i me to recall these matter am perhaps ntraito certainly spy but should not wish to seem suppliant nthe captai had paused i his walk and wa facing his prisone there nwas singula huskiness i his voice a he spoke agai m brune whateve you conscience may permit you to be you saved my nlife at what you must have believed the cost of you ow until saw nyou yesterday whe halted by my sentinel believed you dead thought nthat you had suffered the fate which through my ow crime you might neasily have escaped you had only to step from the ca and leave me to ntake you place before the firing squad you had divine compassio nyou pitied my fatigue you let me sleep watched ove me and a the ntime drew nea fo the relief guard to come and detect me i my crime nyou gently waked me ah brune brune that wa well done that wa ngreat that nthe captai voice failed him the tear were running dow his face and nsparkled upo his beard and his breast resuming his seat at the table nhe buried his face i his arm and sobbed all else wa silence nsuddenly the clea warble of bugle wa heard sounding the assembly nthe captai started and raised his wet face from his arm it had turned nghastly pale outside i the sunlight were heard the sti of the me nfalling into line the voice of the sergeant calling the roll the ntapping of the drummer a they braced thei drum the captai spoke nagai ought to have confessed my fault i orde to relate the story of you nmagnanimity it might have procured you pardo hundred time nresolved to do so but shame prevented besides you sentence wa just nand righteous well heave forgive me said nothing and my regiment nwas soo afterward ordered to tennessee and neve heard about you it wa all right si said brune without visible emotio escaped nand returned to my color the confederate color should like to add nthat before deserting from the federal service had earnestly asked ndischarge o the ground of altered conviction wa answered by npunishment ah but if had suffered the penalty of my crime if you had not ngenerously give me the life that accepted without gratitude you would nnot be agai i the shadow and imminence of death nthe prisone started slightly and look of anxiety came into his face none would have said too that he wa surprised at that moment nlieutenant the adjutant appeared at the opening of the tent and nsaluted captai he said the battalio is formed ncaptai hartroy had recovered his composure he turned to the office nand said lieutenant go to captai graham and say that direct him to nassume command of the battalio and parade it outside the parapet this ngentlema is deserte and spy he is to be shot to death i the npresence of the troop he will accompany you unbound and unguarded nwhile the adjutant waited at the doo the two me inside the tent rose nand exchanged ceremonious bow brune immediately retiring nhalf a hou late a old negro cook the only perso left i camp nexcept the commande wa so startled by the sound of volley of nmusketry that he dropped the kettle that he wa lifting from fire but nfo his consternatio and the hissing which the content of the kettle nmade among the ember he might also have heard neare at hand the nsingle pistol shot with which captai hartroy renounced the life which ni conscience he could no longe keep ni compliance with the term of note that he left fo the office who nsucceeded him i command he wa buried like the deserte and spy nwithout military honor and i the solem shadow of the mountai which nknows no more of wa the two sleep well i long forgotte graf none kind of office ni nof the us of civility captai ransome it is not permitted to you to know _anything_ it is nsufficient that you obey my orde which permit me to repeat if you nperceive any movement of troop i you front you are to ope fire and nif attacked hold this positio a long a you ca do make myself nunderstood si nothing could be plaine lieutenant price this to a office of his now battery who had ridde up i time to hea the orde the general nmeaning is clea is it not perfectly nthe lieutenant passed o to his post fo moment general camero and nthe commande of the battery sat i thei saddle looking at each othe ni silence there wa no more to say apparently too much had already nbee said the the superio office nodded coldly and turned his horse nto ride away the artillerist saluted slowly gravely and with extreme nformality one acquainted with the nicety of military etiquette would nhave said that by his manne he attested sense of the rebuke that he nhad incurred it is one of the important us of civility to signify nresentment nwhe the general had joined his staff and escort awaiting him at nlittle distance the whole cavalcade moved off toward the right of the nguns and vanished i the fog captai ransome wa alone silent nmotionless a a equestria statue the gray fog thickening every nmoment closed i about him like visible doom nii nunde what circumstance me do not wish to be shot nthe fighting of the day before had bee desultory and indecisive at the npoints of collisio the smoke of battle had hung i blue sheet among nthe branch of the tree till beate into nothing by the falling rai ni the softened earth the wheel of canno and ammunitio wagon cut ndeep ragged furrow and movement of infantry seemed impeded by the nmud that clung to the soldier foot a with soake garment and rifle nimperfectly protected by cape of overcoat they went dragging i nsinuous line hithe and thithe through dripping forest and flooded nfield mounted officer thei head protruding from rubbe poncho that nglittered like black armo picked thei way singly and i loose ngroups among the me coming and going with apparent aimlessness and ncommanding attentio from nobody but one anothe here and there dead nma his clothing defiled with earth his face covered with blanket o nshowing yellow and claylike i the rai added his dispiriting influence nto that of the othe dismal feature of the scene and augmented the ngeneral discomfort with particula dejectio very repulsive these nwrecks looked not at all heroic and nobody wa accessible to the ninfectio of thei patriotic example dead upo the field of hono yes nbut the field of hono wa so very wet it make difference nthe general engagement that all expected did not occu none of the nsmall advantage accruing now to this side and now to that i isolated nand accidental collision being followed up half hearted attack nprovoked sulle resistance which wa satisfied with mere repulse norders were obeyed with mechanical fidelity no one did any more tha nhis duty the army is cowardly to day said general camero the commande of nfederal brigade to his adjutant general the army is cold replied the office addressed and yes it doe nwish to be like that nhe pointed to one of the dead body lying i thi pool of yellow nwate it face and clothing bespattered with mud from hoof and wheel nthe army weapon seemed to share it military delinquency the rattle nof rifle sounded flat and contemptible it had no meaning and scarcely nroused to attentio and expectancy the unengaged part of the nline of battle and the waiting reserve heard at little distance the nreports of canno were feeble i volume and _timbre_ they lacked sting nand resonance the gun seemed to be fired with light charge nunshotted and so the futile day wore o to it dreary close and the nto night of discomfort succeeded day of apprehensio na army ha personality beneath the individual thought and emotion nof it component part it think and feel a unit and i this large ninclusive sense of thing lie wise wisdom tha the mere sum of all nthat it know o that dismal morning this great brute force groping at nthe bottom of white ocea of fog among tree that seemed a sea weed nhad dumb consciousness that all wa not well that day manoeuvring nhad resulted i faulty dispositio of it part blind diffusio of nit strength the me felt insecure and talked among themselves of such ntactical error a with thei meage military vocabulary they were able nto name field and line officer gathered i group and spoke more nlearnedly of what they apprehended with no greate clearness commander nof brigade and division looked anxiously to thei connection o the nright and o the left sent staff officer o errand of inquiry and npushed skirmish line silently and cautiously forward into the dubious nregio betwee the know and the unknow at some point o the line the ntroops apparently of thei ow volitio constructed such defense a nthey could without the silent spade and the noisy ax none of these point wa held by captai ransome battery of six gun nprovided always with intrenching tool his me had labored with ndiligence during the night and now his gun thrust thei black muzzle nthrough the embrasure of really formidable earthwork it crowned nslight acclivity devoid of undergrowth and providing a unobstructed nfire that would sweep the ground fo a unknow distance i front the npositio could hardly have bee bette chose it had this peculiarity nwhich captai ransome who wa greatly addicted to the use of the ncompass had not failed to observe it faced northward whereas he knew nthat the general line of the army must face eastward i fact that part nof the line wa refused that is to say bent backward away from the nenemy this implied that captai ransome battery wa somewhere nea nthe left flank of the army fo a army i line of battle retires it nflanks if the nature of the ground will permit they being it nvulnerable point actually captai ransome appeared to hold the nextreme left of the line no troop being visible i that directio nbeyond his ow immediately i rea of his gun occurred that nconversatio betwee him and his brigade commande the concluding and nmore picturesque part of which is reported above niii nhow to play the canno without note ncaptai ransome sat motionless and silent o horseback few yard away nhis me were standing at thei gun somewhere everywhere withi few nmiles were hundred thousand me friend and enemy yet he wa nalone the mist had isolated him a completely a if he had bee i the nheart of desert his world wa few square yard of wet and trampled nearth about the foot of his horse his comrade i that ghostly domai nwere invisible and inaudible these were condition favorable to nthought and he wa thinking of the nature of his thought his nclea cut handsome feature yielded no attesting sig his face wa a ninscrutable a that of the sphinx why should it have made record nwhich there wa none to observe at the sound of footstep he merely nturned his eye i the directio whence it came one of his sergeant nlooking giant i stature i the false perspective of the fog napproached and whe clearly defined and reduced to his true dimension nby propinquity saluted and stood at attentio well morris said the office returning his subordinate salute lieutenant price directed me to tell you si that most of the ninfantry ha bee withdraw we have not sufficient support yes know am to say that some of ou me have bee out ove the work hundred nyards and report that ou front is not picketed yes they were so fa forward that they heard the enemy yes they heard the rattle of the wheel of artillery and the command of nofficers yes the enemy is moving toward ou work ncaptai ransome who had bee facing to the rea of his line toward the npoint where the brigade commande and his cavalcade had bee swallowed nup by the fog reined his horse about and faced the othe way the he nsat motionless a before who are the me who made that statement he inquired without looking nat the sergeant his eye were directed straight into the fog ove the nhead of his horse corporal hassma and gunne manning ncaptai ransome wa moment silent slight pallo came into his face na slight compressio affected the line of his lip but it would have nrequired close observe tha sergeant morris to note the change nthere wa none i the voice sergeant present my compliment to lieutenant price and direct him to nope fire with all the gun grape nthe sergeant saluted and vanished i the fog niv nto introduce general masterso nsearching fo his divisio commande ngeneral camero and his escort had followed the line of battle fo nnearly mile to the right of ransome battery and there learned that nthe divisio commande had gone i search of the corp commande it nseemed that everybody wa looking fo his immediate superio a ominous ncircumstance it meant that nobody wa quite at ease so general camero nrode o fo anothe half mile where by good luck he met general nmasterso the divisio commande returning ah camero said the highe office reining up and throwing his nright leg across the pommel of his saddle i most unmilitary way anything up found good positio fo you battery hope if one nplace is bette tha anothe i fog yes general said the othe with the of his opinio by the way i orde to occupy the hill nthat he hold had to extend my line dangerously the hill is o my nleft that is to say the left flank of the army oh no hart brigade is beyond it wa ordered up from drytow during nthe night and directed to hook o to you bette go and nthe sentence wa unfinished lively cannonade had broke out o the nleft and both officer followed by thei retinue of aide and norderlies making great jingle and clank rode rapidly toward the spot nbut they were soo impeded fo they were compelled by the fog to keep nwithi sight of the line of battle behind which were swarm of me all ni motio across thei way everywhere the line wa assuming sharpe nand harde definitio a the me sprang to arm and the officer with ndraw sword dressed the rank colo bearer unfurled the flag nbuglers blew the assembly hospital attendant appeared with nstretchers field officer mounted and sent thei impedimenta to the nrea i care of negro servant back i the ghostly space of the forest ncould be heard the rustle and murmu of the reserve pulling themselves ntogethe nno wa all this preparatio vai fo scarcely five minute had passed nsince captai ransome gun had broke the truce of doubt before the nwhole regio wa aroa the enemy had attacked nearly everywhere nv nhow sound ca fight shadow ncaptai ransome walked up and dow behind his gun which were firing nrapidly but with steadiness the gunner worked alertly but without nhaste o apparent excitement there wa really no reaso fo excitement nit is not much to point canno into fog and fire it anybody ca do na much a that nthe me smiled at thei noisy work performing it with lessening nalacrity they cast curious regard upo thei captai who had now nmounted the banquette of the fortificatio and wa looking across the nparapet a if observing the effect of his fire but the only visible neffect wa the substitutio of wide low lying sheet of smoke fo thei nbulk of fog suddenly out of the obscurity burst great sound of ncheering which filled the interval betwee the report of the gun nwith startling distinctness to the few with leisure and opportunity to nobserve the sound wa inexpressibly strange so loud so nea so nmenacing yet nothing see the me who had smiled at thei work smiled nno more but performed it with serious and feverish activity nfrom his statio at the parapet captai ransome now saw great nmultitude of dim gray figure taking shape i the mist below him and nswarming up the slope but the work of the gun wa now fast and nfurious they swept the populous declivity with gust of grape and ncaniste the whirring of which could be heard through the thunde of nthe explosion i this awful tempest of iro the assailant struggled nforward foot by foot across thei dead firing into the embrasure nreloading firing agai and at last falling i thei tu little i nadvance of those who had falle before soo the smoke wa dense enough nto cove all it settled dow upo the attack and drifting back ninvolved the defense the gunner could hardly see to serve thei npieces and whe occasional figure of the enemy appeared upo the nparapet having had the good luck to get nea enough to it betwee two nembrasures to be protected from the gun they looked so unsubstantial nthat it seemed hardly worth while fo the few infantryme to go to work nupo them with the bayonet and tumble them back into the ditch na the commande of battery i actio ca find something bette to do ntha cracking individual skull captai ransome had retired from the nparapet to his prope post i rea of his gun where he stood with nfolded arm his bugle beside him here during the hottest of the nfight he wa approached by lieutenant price who had just sabred ndaring assailant inside the work spirited colloquy ensued betwee the ntwo officer spirited at least o the part of the lieutenant who ngesticulated with energy and shouted agai and agai into his ncommande ea i the attempt to make himself heard above the infernal ndi of the gun his gesture if coolly noted by a acto would have nbee pronounced to be those of protestatio one would have said that he nwas opposed to the proceeding did he wish to surrende ncaptai ransome listened without change of countenance o attitude nand whe the othe ma had finished his harangue looked him coldly i nthe eye and during seasonable abatement of the uproa said lieutenant price it is not permitted to you to know _anything_ it is nsufficient that you obey my order nthe lieutenant went to his post and the parapet being now apparently nclea captai ransome returned to it to have look ove a he mounted nthe banquette ma sprang upo the crest waving great brilliant nflag the captai drew pistol from his belt and shot him dead the nbody pitching forward hung ove the inne edge of the embankment the narms straight downward both hand still grasping the flag the ma nfew follower turned and fled dow the slope looking ove the parapet nthe captai saw no living thing he observed also that no bullet were ncoming into the work nhe made sig to the bugle who sounded the command to cease firing nat all othe point the actio had already ended with repulse of the nconfederate attack with the cessatio of this cannonade the silence wa nabsolute nvi nwhy being affronted by it is not best to affront ngeneral masterso rode into the redoubt the me gathered i group nwere talking loudly and gesticulating they pointed at the dead running nfrom one body to anothe they neglected thei foul and heated gun and nforgot to resume thei oute clothing they ra to the parapet and nlooked ove some of them leaping dow into the ditch score were ngathered about flag rigidly held by dead ma well my me said the general cheerily you have had pretty fight nof it nthey stared nobody replied the presence of the great ma seemed to nembarrass and alarm ngetting no response to his pleasant condescensio the easy mannered noffice whistled ba o two of popula ai and riding forward to nthe parapet looked ove at the dead i a instant he had whirled his nhorse about and wa spurring along i rea of the gun his eye neverywhere at once a office sat o the trail of one of the gun nsmoking ciga a the general dashed up he rose and tranquilly nsaluted captai ransome the word fell sharp and harsh like the clash of nsteel blade you have bee fighting ou ow me ou ow me si do nyou hea hart brigade general know that you know it you know that and you sit here smoking oh dam it nhamilto m losing my tempe this to his provost marshal si ncaptai ransome be good enough to say to say why you fought ou ow nme that am unable to say i my were nattacking ou ow me nthe reply wa astounding knew that general it appeared to be none of my business nthe breaking the dead silence that followed his answe he said must refe you to general camero general camero is dead si a dead a he ca be a dead a any ma ni this army he lie back yonde unde tree do you mea to say that nhe had anything to do with this horrible business ncaptai ransome did not reply observing the altercatio his me had ngathered about to watch the outcome they were greatly excited the fog nwhich had bee partly dissipated by the firing had agai closed i so ndarkly about them that they drew more closely togethe till the judge o nhorseback and the accused standing calmly before him had but narrow nspace free from intrusio it wa the most informal of court martial nbut all felt that the formal one to follow would but affirm it njudgment it had no jurisdictio but it had the significance of nprophecy captai ransome the general cried impetuously but with something i nhis voice that wa almost entreaty if you ca say anything to put nbette light upo you incomprehensible conduct beg you will do so nhaving recovered his tempe this generous soldie sought fo something nto justify his naturally sympathetic attitude toward brave ma i the nimminence of dishonorable death where is lieutenant price the captai said nthat office stood forward his dark saturnine face looking somewhat nforbidding unde bloody handkerchief bound about his brow he nunderstood the summons and needed no invitatio to speak he did not nlook at the captai but addressed the general during the engagement discovered the state of affair and apprised nthe commande of the battery ventured to urge that the firing cease ni wa insulted and ordered to my post do you know anything of the order unde which wa acting asked the ncaptai of any order unde which the commande of the battery wa acting the nlieutenant continued still addressing the general know nothing ncaptai ransome felt his world sink away from his foot i those cruel nwords he heard the murmu of the century breaking upo the shore of neternity he heard the voice of doom it said i cold mechanical and nmeasured tone ready aim fire and he felt the bullet tea his nheart to shred he heard the sound of the earth upo his coffi and if nthe good god wa so merciful the song of bird above his forgotte ngrave quietly detaching his sabre from it support he handed it up to nthe provost marshal none office one ma ncaptai graffenreid stood at the head of his company the regiment wa nnot engaged it formed part of the front line of battle which nstretched away to the right with visible length of nearly two mile nthrough the ope ground the left flank wa veiled by wood to the nright also the line wa lost to sight but it extended many mile nhundred yard i rea wa second line behind this the reserve nbrigades and division i colum battery of artillery occupied the nspaces betwee and crowned the low hill group of horseme general nwith thei staff and escort and field officer of regiment behind nthe color broke the regularity of the line and column number of nthese figure of interest had field glass at thei eye and sat nmotionless stolidly scanning the country i front others came nand went at slow cante bearing order there were squad of nstretche bearer ambulance wago train with ammunitio and nofficers servant i rea of all of all that wa visible fo still i nrea of these along the road extended fo many mile all that vast nmultitude of no combatant who with thei various _impedimenta_ are nassigned to the inglorious but important duty of supplying the fighter nmany need na army i line of battle awaiting attack o prepared to delive it npresents strange contrast at the front are precisio formality nfixity and silence toward the rea these characteristic are le and nless conspicuous and finally i point of space are lost altogethe i nconfusio motio and noise the homogeneous becomes heterogeneous ndefinitio is lacking repose is replaced by a apparently purposeless nactivity harmony vanishes i hubbub form i disorde commotio neverywhere and ceaseless unrest the me who do not fight are neve nready nfrom his positio at the right of his company i the front rank captai ngraffenreid had a unobstructed outlook toward the enemy half mile of nope and nearly level ground lay before him and beyond it a irregula nwood covering slight acclivity not huma being anywhere visible nhe could imagine nothing more peaceful tha the appearance of that npleasant landscape with it long stretch of brow field ove which nthe atmosphere wa beginning to quive i the heat of the morning su nnot sound came from forest o field not eve the barking of dog o nthe crowing of cock at the half see plantatio house o the crest namong the tree yet every ma i those mile of me knew that he and ndeath were face to face ncaptai graffenreid had neve i his life see a armed enemy and the nwa i which his regiment wa one of the first to take the field wa two nyears old he had had the rare advantage of military educatio and nwhe his comrade had marched to the front he had bee detached fo nadministrative service at the capital of his state where it wa thought nthat he could be most useful like bad soldie he protested and like na good one obeyed i close official and personal relation with the ngoverno of his state and enjoying his confidence and favo he had nfirmly refused promotio and see his junior elevated above him death nhad bee busy i his distant regiment vacancy among the field nofficers had occurred agai and agai but from chivalrous feeling nthat wa reward belonged of right to those who bore the storm and nstress of battle he had held his humble rank and generously advanced the nfortunes of others his silent devotio to principle had conquered at nlast he had bee relieved of his hateful duty and ordered to the nfront and now untried by fire stood i the va of battle i command nof company of hardy veteran to whom he had bee only name and nthat name by word by none not eve by those of his brothe officer ni whose favo he had waived his right wa his devotio to duty nunderstood they were too busy to be just he wa looked upo a one who nhad shirked his duty until forced unwillingly into the field too proud nto explai yet not too insensible to feel he could only endure and nhope nof all the federal army o that summe morning none had accepted battle nmore joyously tha anderto graffenreid his spirit wa buoyant his nfaculties were riotous he wa i state of mental exaltatio and nscarcely could endure the enemy tardiness i advancing to the attack nto him this wa opportunity fo the result he cared nothing victory o ndefeat a god might will i one o i the othe he should prove nhimself soldie and hero he should vindicate his right to the nrespect of his me and the companionship of his brothe officer to the nconsideratio of his superior how his heart leaped i his breast a nthe bugle sounded the stirring note of the assembly with what nlight tread scarcely conscious of the earth beneath his foot he strode nforward at the head of his company and how exultingly he noted the ntactical disposition which placed his regiment i the front line and nif perchance some memory came to him of pai of dark eye that might ntake o tendere light i reading the account of that day doings nwho shall blame him fo the unmartial thought o count it debasement nof soldierly ardo nsuddenly from the forest half mile i front apparently from among nthe uppe branch of the tree but really from the ridge beyond rose na tall colum of white smoke moment late came deep jarring nexplosio followed almost attended by hideous rushing sound that nseemed to leap forward across the intervening space with inconceivable nrapidity rising from whispe to roa with too quick gradatio fo nattentio to note the successive stage of it horrible progressio nvisible tremo ra along the line of me all were startled into nmotio captai graffenreid dodged and threw up his hand to one side of nhis head palm outward na he did so he heard kee ringing report and saw o hillside nbehind the line fierce roll of smoke and dust the shell explosio nit had passed hundred foot to his left he heard o fancied he heard na low mocking laugh and turning i the directio whence it came saw the neyes of his first lieutenant fixed upo him with a unmistakable look of namusement he looked along the line of face i the front rank the me nwere laughing at him the thought restored the colo to his bloodless nface restored too much of it his cheek burned with feve of shame nthe enemy shot wa not answered the office i command at that nexposed part of the line had evidently no desire to provoke cannonade nfo the forbearance captai graffenreid wa conscious of sense of ngratitude he had not know that the flight of projectile wa nphenomeno of so appalling characte his conceptio of wa had already nundergone profound change and he wa conscious that his new feeling nwas manifesting itself i visible perturbatio his blood wa boiling i nhis vein he had choking sensatio and felt that if he had command nto give it would be inaudible o at least unintelligible the hand i nwhich he held his sword trembled the othe moved automatically nclutching at various part of his clothing he found difficulty i nstanding still and fancied that his me observed it wa it fea he nfeared it wa nfrom somewhere away to the right came a the wind served low nintermittent murmu like that of ocea i storm like that of ndistant railway trai like that of thei field glass that nway mingled with the sound wa a irregula throbbing he thought it nat first the beating of his fevered blood i his ear next the ndistant tapping of bass drum the ball is opened o the right flank said a office ncaptai graffenreid understood the sound were musketry and artillery nhe nodded and tried to smile there wa apparently nothing infectious i nthe smile npresently light line of blue smoke puff broke out along the edge of nthe wood i front succeeded by crackle of rifle there were kee nsharp hissing i the ai terminating abruptly with thump nea by nthe ma at captai graffenreid side dropped his rifle his knee gave nway and he pitched awkwardly forward falling upo his face somebody nshouted lie dow and the dead ma wa hardly distinguishable from the nliving it looked a if those few rifle shot had slai te thousand nme only the field officer remained erect thei concessio to the nemergency consisted i dismounting and sending thei horse to the nshelte of the low hill immediately i rea ncaptai graffenreid lay alongside the dead ma from beneath whose nbreast flowed little rill of blood it had faint sweetish odo that nsickened him the face wa crushed into the earth and flattened it nlooked yellow already and wa repulsive nothing suggested the glory of na soldie death no mitigated the loathsomeness of the incident he ncould not tu his back upo the body without facing away from his ncompany nhe fixed his eye upo the forest where all agai wa silent he tried nto imagine what wa going o there the line of troop forming to nattack the gun being pushed forward by hand to the edge of the ope nhe fancied he could see thei black muzzle protruding from the nundergrowth ready to delive thei storm of missile such missile a nthe one whose shriek had so unsettled his nerve the distensio of his neyes became painful mist seemed to gathe before them he could no nlonge see across the field yet would not withdraw his gaze lest he see nthe dead ma at his side nthe fire of battle wa not now burning very brightly i this warrio nsoul from inactio had come introspectio he sought rathe to analyze nhis feeling tha distinguish himself by courage and devotio the nresult wa profoundly disappointing he covered his face with his hand nand groaned aloud nthe hoarse murmu of battle grew more and more distinct upo the right nthe murmu had indeed become roa the throbbing thunde the nsounds had worked round obliquely to the front evidently the enemy nleft wa being drive back and the propitious moment to move against nthe salient angle of his line would soo arrive the silence and mystery ni front were ominous all felt that they boded evil to the assailant nbehind the prostrate line sounded the hoofbeats of galloping horse nthe me turned to look doze staff officer were riding to the nvarious brigade and regimental commander who had remounted moment nmore and there wa chorus of voice all uttering out of time the same nwords attentio battalio the me sprang to thei foot and were naligned by the company commander they awaited the word forward nawaited too with beating heart and set teeth the gust of lead and niro that were to smite them at thei first movement i obedience to nthat word the word wa not give the tempest did not break out the ndelay wa hideous maddening it unnerved like respite at the nguillotine ncaptai graffenreid stood at the head of his company the dead ma at nhis foot he heard the battle o the right rattle and crash of nmusketry ceaseless thunde of canno desultory cheer of invisible ncombatants he marked ascending cloud of smoke from distant forest he nnoted the siniste silence of the forest i front these contrasting nextremes affected the whole range of his sensibility the strai upo nhis nervous organizatio wa insupportable he grew hot and cold by nturns he panted like dog and the forgot to breathe until reminded nby vertigo nsuddenly he grew calm glancing downward his eye had falle upo his nnaked sword a he held it point to earth foreshortened to his view nit resembled somewhat he thought the short heavy blade of the ancient nroma the fancy wa full of suggestio malig fateful heroic nthe sergeant i the rea rank immediately behind captai graffenreid nnow observed strange sight his attentio draw by a uncommo nmovement made by the captai sudde reaching forward of the hand and nthei energetic withdrawal throwing the elbow out a i pulling a noa he saw spring from betwee the office shoulder bright point nof metal which prolonged itself outward nearly half arm length nblade it wa faintly streaked with crimso and it point approached so nnea to the sergeant breast and with so quick movement that he nshrank backward i alarm that moment captai graffenreid pitched nheavily forward upo the dead ma and died na week late the majo general commanding the left corp of the federal narmy submitted the following official report si have the hono to report with regard to the actio of the 19th ninst that owing to the enemy withdrawal from my front to reinforce nhis beate left my command wa not seriously engaged my loss wa a nfollows killed one office one ma ngeorge thursto nthree incident i the life of ma ngeorge thursto wa first lieutenant and aide de camp o the staff of ncolonel brough commanding federal brigade colonel brough wa only ntemporarily i command a senio colonel the brigadie general having nbee severely wounded and granted leave of absence to recove nlieutenant thursto wa believe of colonel brough regiment to nwhich with his chief he would naturally have bee relegated had he nlived till ou brigade commande recovery the aide whose place nthursto took had bee killed i battle thursto advent among u wa nthe only change i the _personnel_ of ou staff consequent upo the nchange i commander we did not like him he wa unsocial this nhoweve wa more observed by others tha by me whethe i camp o o nthe march i barrack i tent o _e bivouac_ my duty a ntopographical enginee kept me working like beave all day i the nsaddle and half the night at my drawing table platting my survey it nwas hazardous work the neare to the enemy line could penetrate nthe more valuable were my field note and the resulting map it wa nbusiness i which the life of me counted a nothing against the chance nof defining road o sketching bridge whole squadron of cavalry nescort had sometimes to be sent thundering against powerful infantry noutpost i orde that the brief time betwee the charge and the ninevitable retreat might be utilized i sounding ford o determining nthe point of intersectio of two road ni some of the dark corner of england and wale they have a immemorial ncustom of beating the bound of the parish o certai day of the nyea the whole populatio turn out and travel i processio from one nlandmark to anothe o the boundary line at the most important point nlads are soundly beate with rod to make them remembe the place i nafte life they become authority ou frequent engagement with the nconfederate outpost patrol and scouting party had incidentally nthe same educating value they fixed i my memory vivid and apparently nimperishable picture of the locality picture serving instead of naccurate field note which indeed it wa not always convenient to ntake with carbine cracking saber clashing and horse plunging all nabout these spirited encounter were observation entered i red none morning a set out at the head of my escort o a expeditio of nmore tha the usual hazard lieutenant thursto rode up alongside and nasked if had any objectio to his accompanying me the colonel ncommanding having give him permissio none whateve replied rathe gruffly but i what capacity will nyou go you are not topographical enginee and captai burling ncommands my escort will go a spectato he said removing his sword belt and taking nthe pistol from his holster he handed them to his servant who took nthem back to headquarters realized the brutality of my remark but nnot clearly seeing my way to a apology said nothing nthat afternoo we encountered whole regiment of the enemy cavalry i nline and field piece that dominated straight mile of the turnpike by nwhich we had approached my escort fought deployed i the wood o both nsides but thursto remained i the cente of the road which at nintervals of few second wa swept by gust of grape and caniste that ntore the ai wide ope a they passed he had dropped the rei o the nneck of his horse and sat bolt upright i the saddle with folded arm nsoo he wa dow his horse to to piece from the side of the road nmy pencil and field book idle my duty forgotte watched him slowly ndisengaging himself from the wreck and rising at that instant the ncanno having ceased firing burly confederate troope o spirited nhorse dashed like thunderbolt dow the road with draw sabe thursto nsaw him coming drew himself up to his full height and agai folded his narms he wa too brave to retreat before the word and my uncivil word nhad disarmed him he wa spectato anothe moment and he would have nbee split like mackerel but blessed bullet tumbled his assailant ninto the dusty road so nea that the impetus sent the body rolling to nthursto foot that evening while platting my hasty survey found ntime to frame a apology which think took the rude primitive form of na confessio that had spoke like malicious idiot na few week late part of ou army made a assault upo the enemy nleft the attack which wa made upo a unknow positio and across nunfamilia ground wa led by ou brigade the ground wa so broke and nthe underbrush so thick that all mounted officer and me were compelled nto fight o foot the brigade commande and his staff included i the n_m xc3 xaal xc3 xa9e_ thursto wa parted from the rest of u and we found him nhorribly wounded only whe we had take the enemy last defense he nwas some month i hospital at nashville tennessee but finally nrejoined u he said little about his misadventure except that he had nbee bewildered and had strayed into the enemy line and bee shot ndow but from one of his captor whom we i tu had captured we nlearned the particular he came walking right upo u a we lay i nline said this ma whole company of u instantly sprang up and nleveled ou rifle at his breast some of them almost touching him throw dow that sword and surrende you damned yank shouted some one ni authority the fellow ra his eye along the line of rifle barrel nfolded his arm across his breast his right hand still clutching his nsword and deliberately replied will not if we had all fired he nwould have bee to to shred some of u did i did fo one nnothing could have induced me nwhe one is tranquilly looking death i the eye and refusing him any nconcessio one naturally ha good opinio of one self do know nif it wa this feeling that i thursto found expressio i stiffish nattitude and folded arm at the mess table one day i his absence nanothe explanatio wa suggested by ou quartermaste a irreclaimable nstammere whe the wine wa i it h is ay of m mastering nc consti tu tional tendency to u aw ay what flamed out indignantly rising you intimate that thursto is na coward and i his absence if he ere cow wow ard e would t try to m maste it nand if he ere present w would d dare to d discus it nwas the mollifying reply nthis intrepid ma george thursto died a ignoble death the brigade nwas i camp with headquarters i grove of immense tree to a uppe nbranch of one of these venturesome climbe had attached the two end nof long rope and made swing with length of not le tha one nhundred foot plunging downward from height of fifty foot along the narc of circle with such radius soaring to a equal altitude npausing fo one breathless instant the sweeping dizzily backward no none who ha not tried it ca conceive the terror of such sport to the nnovice thursto came out of his tent one day and asked fo instructio ni the mystery of propelling the swing the art of rising and sitting nwhich every boy ha mastered i few moment he had acquired the trick nand wa swinging highe tha the most experienced of u had dared we nshuddered to look at his fearful flight st top him said the quartermaste snailing lazily along from the nmess tent where he had bee lunching e doe know that if e ng go clea ove e ll ind up the sw ing nwith such energy wa that strong ma cannonading himself through the ai nthat at each extremity of his increasing arc his body standing i the nswing wa almost horizontal should he once pas above the level of the nrope attachment he would be lost the rope would slacke and he would nfall vertically to point a fa below a he had gone above and the nthe sudde tensio of the rope would wrest it from his hand all saw nthe peril all cried out to him to desist and gesticulated at him a nindistinct and with noise like the rush of canno shot i flight he nswept past u through the lowe reach of his hideous oscillatio nwoma standing at little distance away fainted and fell unobserved nme from the camp of regiment nea by ra i crowd to see all nshouting suddenly a thursto wa o his upward curve the shout all nceased nthursto and the swing had parted that is all that ca be know both nhands at once had released the rope the impetus of the light swing nexhausted it wa falling back the ma momentum wa carrying him nalmost erect upward and forward no longe i his arc but with a noutward curve it could have bee but a instant yet it seemed a age ni cried out o thought cried out my god will he neve stop going nup he passed close to the branch of tree remembe feeling of ndelight a thought he would clutch it and save himself speculated no the possibility of it sustaining his weight he passed above it and nfrom my point of view wa sharply outlined against the blue at this ndistance of many year ca distinctly recall that image of ma i nthe sky it head erect it foot close togethe it hand do not nsee it hand all at once with astonishing suddenness and rapidity it nturns clea ove and pitch downward there is anothe cry from the ncrowd which ha rushed instinctively forward the ma ha become merely na whirling object mostly leg the there is a indescribable sound nthe sound of a impact that shake the earth and these bent beneath wa broke above nthe knee and the bone drive into the earth the abdome had burst the nbowels protruded the neck wa broke nthe arm were folded tightly across the breast nthe mocking bird nthe time pleasant sunday afternoo i the early autum of 1861 the nplace forest heart i the mountai regio of southweste virginia nprivate grayrock of the federal army is discovered seated comfortably at nthe root of great pine tree against which he lean his leg extended nstraight along the ground his rifle lying across his thigh his hand clasped i orde that they may not fall away to his side resting upo nthe barrel of the weapo the contact of the back of his head with the ntree ha pushed his cap downward ove his eye almost concealing them none seeing him would say that he slept nprivate grayrock did not sleep to have done so would have imperiled the ninterests of the united state fo he wa long way outside the line nand subject to capture o death at the hand of the enemy moreove he nwas i frame of mind unfavorable to repose the cause of his nperturbatio of spirit wa this during the previous night he had served no the picket guard and had bee posted a sentinel i this very nforest the night wa clea though moonless but i the gloom of the nwood the darkness wa deep grayrock post wa at considerable ndistance from those to right and left fo the picket had bee throw nout needle distance from the camp making the line too long fo the nforce detailed to occupy it the wa wa young and military camp nentertained the erro that while sleeping they were bette protected by nthi line long way out toward the enemy tha by thicke one close ni and surely they needed a long notice a possible of a enemy napproach fo they were at that time addicted to the practice of nundressing tha which nothing could be more unsoldierly o the morning nof the memorable 6th of april at shiloh many of grant me whe nspitted o confederate bayonet were a naked a civilian but it nshould be allowed that this wa not because of any defect i thei npicket line thei erro wa of anothe sort they had no picket this ni perhaps vai digressio should not care to undertake to interest nthe reade i the fate of a army what we have here to conside is that nof private grayrock nfo two hour afte he had bee left at his lonely post that saturday nnight he stood stock still leaning against the trunk of large tree nstaring into the darkness i his front and trying to recognize know nobjects fo he had bee posted at the same spot during the day but all nwas now different he saw nothing i detail but only group of thing nwhose shape not observed whe there wa something more of them to nobserve were now unfamilia they seemed not to have bee there before na landscape that is all tree and undergrowth moreove lack ndefinitio is confused and without accentuated point upo which nattentio ca gai foothold add the gloom of moonless night and nsomething more tha great natural intelligence and city educatio is nrequired to preserve one knowledge of directio and that is how it noccurred that private grayrock afte vigilantly watching the space i nhis front and the imprudently executing circumspectio of his whole ndimly visible environment silently walking around his tree to naccomplish it lost his bearing and seriously impaired his usefulness na sentinel lost at his post unable to say i which directio to nlook fo a enemy approach and i which lay the sleeping camp fo nwhose security he wa accountable with his life conscious too of many nanothe awkward feature of the situatio and of consideration affecting nhis ow safety private grayrock wa profoundly disquieted no wa he ngive time to recove his tranquillity fo almost at the moment that he nrealized his awkward predicament he heard sti of leaf and snap of nfalle twig and turning with stilled heart i the directio whence nit came saw i the gloom the indistinct outline of huma figure halt shouted private grayrock peremptorily a i duty bound backing nup the command with the sharp metallic snap of his cocking rifle who ngoes there nthere wa no answe at least there wa a instant hesitatio and the nanswe if it came wa lost i the report of the sentinel rifle i nthe silence of the night and the forest the sound wa deafening and nhardly had it died away whe it wa repeated by the piece of the npickets to right and left sympathetic fusillade fo two hour every nunconverted civilia of them had bee evolving enemy from his nimaginatio and peopling the wood i his front with them and ngrayrock shot had started the whole encroaching host into visible nexistence having fired all retreated breathless to the reserve all nbut grayrock who did not know i what directio to retreat whe no nenemy appearing the roused camp two mile away had undressed and got nitself into bed agai and the picket line wa cautiously nre established he wa discovered bravely holding his ground and wa ncomplimented by the office of the guard a the one soldie of that ndevoted band who could rightly be considered the moral equivalent of nthat uncommo unit of value whoop i hell ni the mea time howeve grayrock had made close but unavailing nsearch fo the mortal part of the intrude at whom he had fired and nwhom he had marksma intuitive sense of having hit fo he wa one nof those bo expert who shoot without aim by a instinctive sense of ndirectio and are nearly a dangerous by night a by day during full nhalf of his twenty fou year he had bee terro to the target of all nthe shooting gallery i three city unable now to produce his dead ngame he had the discretio to hold his tongue and wa glad to observe ni his office and comrade the natural assumptio that not having ru naway he had see nothing hostile his honorable mentio had bee nearned by not running away anyhow nnevertheless private grayrock wa fa from satisfied with the night nadventure and whe the next day he made some fai enough pretext to napply fo pas to go outside the line and the general commanding npromptly granted it i recognitio of his bravery the night before he npassed out at the point where that had bee displayed telling the nsentinel the o duty there that he had lost something which wa true nenough he renewed the search fo the perso whom he supposed himself to nhave shot and whom if only wounded he hoped to trail by the blood he nwas no more successful by daylight tha he had bee i the darkness and nafte covering wide area and boldly penetrating long distance into the confederacy he gave up the search somewhat fatigued seated nhimself at the root of the great pine tree where we have see him and nindulged his disappointment nit is not to be inferred that grayrock wa the chagri of cruel nnature balked of it bloody deed i the clea large eye finely nwrought lip and broad forehead of that young ma one could read quite nanothe story and i point of fact his characte wa singularly nfelicitous compound of boldness and sensibility courage and conscience find myself disappointed he said to himself sitting there at the nbottom of the golde haze submerging the forest like subtle sea disappointed i failing to discove fellow ma dead by my hand do nthe really wish that had take life i the performance of duty a nwell performed without what more could wish if any dange nthreatened my shot averted it that is what wa there to do no am nglad indeed if no huma the fusillade and did not retreat i the ngeneral alarm because bewildered what the shall do explai that nsaw a enemy and fired they have all said that of themselves yet none nbelieves it shall tell truth which discrediting my courage will nhave the effect of lie ugh it is a ugly business altogethe wish nto god could find my ma nand so wishing private grayrock overcome at last by the languo of the nafternoo and lulled by the stilly sound of insect droning and prosing ni certai fragrant shrub so fa forgot the interest of the united nstates a to fall asleep and expose himself to capture and sleeping he ndreamed nhe thought himself boy living i fa fai land by the borde of ngreat rive upo which the tall steamboat moved grandly up and dow nbeneath thei towering evolution of black smoke which announced them nlong before they had rounded the bend and marked thei movement whe nmiles out of sight with him always at his side a he watched them wa none to whom he gave his heart and soul i only childre of widowed mothe walked ni path of light through valley of peace seeing new thing unde nnew su and through all the golde day floated one unceasing sound nthe rich thrilling melody of mocking bird i cage by the cottage ndoo it pervaded and possessed all the spiritual interval of the ndream like musical benedictio the joyous bird wa always i song nit infinitely various note seemed to flow from it throat effortless ni bubble and rill at each heart beat like the water of pulsing nspring that fresh clea melody seemed indeed the spirit of the nscene the meaning and interpretatio to mean npermit nthirty year ago joh hardshaw and his wife lived o rinco hill i one nof the finest residence of that once aristocratic quarte he had once nbee physicia but having inherited considerable with he two nchildre of whom mr hardshaw childless herself grew fond nunluckily he husband grew equally fond of thei mothe good deal nfonde still more unluckily that attractive lady wa le wise tha nweak nat about three clock one autum morning office no 13 of the nsacramento police saw ma stealthily leaving the rea entrance of ngentlema residence and promptly arrested him the ma who wore nslouch with virtuous contempt before reaching the statio the nprisone agreed to give him check fo te thousand dollar and remai nironed i the willow along the rive bank until it should be paid a nthis only him ninto the street and kicked his assistant afte him the insulted majesty nof the law wa not vindicated the victim of the indignity did not eve nmentio anything of all this i court he wa ambitious to wi his case nand the circumstance of the taking of that depositio were not such a nwould give it weight if related and afte all the ma o trial had ncommitted a offense against the law majesty only with that kee nsense fo visible characteristic which eve distinguishes the young nmale of ou specie sometimes mentioned him among themselves by the nname of spoony glum nit occurred one day that joh hardshaw wa possessed by the spirit of nunrest god know what led him whithe he went but he crossed market nstreet and held his way northward ove the hill and downward into the nregio know a north beach turning aimlessly to the left he followed nhis toe along a unfamilia street until he wa opposite what fo that nperiod wa rathe grand dwelling and fo this is rathe shabby nfactory casting his eye casually upward he saw at a ope window what nit had bee bette that he had not see the face and figure of elvira nbarwell thei eye met with sharp exclamatio like the cry of nstartled bird the lady sprang to he foot and thrust he body half out nof the window clutching the casing o each side arrested by the cry nthe people i the street below looked up hardshaw stood motionless nspeechless his eye two flame take care shouted some one i the ncrowd a the woma strained furthe and furthe forward defying the nsilent implacable law of gravitatio a once she had defied that othe nlaw which god thundered from sinai the suddenness of he movement had ntumbled torrent of dark hai dow he shoulder and now it wa blow nabout he cheek almost concealing he face moment so and the nfearful cry rang through the street a losing he balance she pitched nheadlong from the window confused and whirling mass of skirt limb nhai and white face and struck the pavement with horrible sound and na force of impact that wa felt hundred foot away fo moment all neyes refused thei office and turned from the sickening spectacle o the nsidewalk draw agai to that horro they saw it strangely augmented nma hatless seated flat upo the paving stone held the broke nbleeding body against his breast kissing the mangled cheek and nstreaming mouth through tangle of wet hai his ow feature nindistinguishably a njohnso no longe passed yea i the stockto asylum fo the insane nwhere also through the influence of pitying friend his wife wa nadmitted to care fo him whe he wa discharged not cured but nharmless they returned to the city it would seem eve to have had some ndreadful fascinatio fo them fo time they lived nea the missio ndolores i poverty only le abject tha that which is thei present nlot but it eage and cheerful look a he take it the retu njourney appears to be trifle wearisome na adventure at brownville 1 1 this story wa writte i collaboratio with miss ina lillia npeterso to whom is rightly the finest scenery i california the tow is nsomewhat frequented i summe by class of person whom it is the habit nof the local journal to call pleasure seeker but who by juste nclassificatio would be know a the sick and those i adversity nbrownville itself might rightly enough be described indeed a summe nplace of last resort it is fairly well endowed with boarding house at nthe least pernicious of which performed twice day lunching at the nschoolhouse the humble rite of cementing the alliance betwee soul and nbody from this hostelry a the local journal preferred to call it nwhe it did not call it caravanserai to the schoolhouse the ndistance by the wago road wa about mile and half but there wa ntrail very little used which led ove a intervening range of low nheavily wooded hill considerably shortening the distance by this ntrail wa returning one evening late tha usual it wa the last day nof the term and had bee detained at the schoolhouse until almost ndark preparing a account of my stewardship fo the trustee two of nwhom proudly reflected would be able to read it and the third a ninstance of the dominio of mind ove matte would be overruled i his ncustomary antagonism to the schoolmaste of his ow creatio ni had gone not more tha quarte of the way whe finding a interest ni the antic of family of lizard which dwelt thereabout and seemed nfull of reptilia joy fo thei immunity from the ill incident to life nat the brownville house sat upo falle tree to observe them a nleaned wearily against branch of the gnarled old trunk the twilight ndeepened i the sombe wood and the faint new moo bega casting nvisible shadow and gilding the leaf of the tree with tende but nghostly light ni heard the sound of voice woma angry impetuous rising against ndeep masculine tone rich and musical strained my eye peering nthrough the dusky shadow of the wood hoping to get view of the nintruders o my solitude but could see no one fo some yard i each ndirectio had a uninterrupted view of the trail and knowing of no nothe withi half mile thought the person heard must be approaching nfrom the wood at one side there wa no sound but that of the voice nwhich were now so distinct that could catch the word that of the ma ngave me a impressio of ange abundantly confirmed by the matte nspoke will have no threat you are powerless a you very well know let nthings remai a they are o by god you shall both suffe fo it what do you mea this wa the voice of the woma cultivated nvoice the voice of lady you would not murde u nthere wa no reply at least none that wa audible to me during the nsilence peered into the wood i hope to get glimpse of the speaker nfo felt sure that this wa a affai of gravity i which ordinary nscruples ought not to count it seemed to me that the woma wa i nperil at any rate the ma had not disavowed willingness to murde nwhe ma is enacting the xc3 xb4le of potential assassi he ha not the nright to choose his audience nafte some little time saw them indistinct i the moonlight among the ntrees the ma tall and slende seemed clothed i black the woma nwore a nearly a could make out gow of gray stuff evidently nthey were still unaware of my presence i the shadow though fo some nreaso whe they renewed thei conversatio they spoke i lowe tone nand could no longe understand a looked the woma seemed to sink nto the ground and raise he hand i supplicatio a is frequently done no the stage and neve so fa a knew anywhere else and am now nnot altogethe sure that it wa done i this instance the ma fixed his neyes upo he they seemed to glitte bleakly i the moonlight with a nexpressio that made me apprehensive that he would tu them upo me ndo not know by what impulse wa moved but sprang to my foot out of nthe shadow at that instant the figure vanished peered i vai nthrough the space among the tree and clump of undergrowth the night nwind rustled the leaf the lizard had retired early reptile of nexemplary habit the little moo wa already slipping behind black nhill i the west ni went home somewhat disturbed i mind half doubting that had heard no see any living thing excepting the lizard it all seemed trifle nodd and uncanny it wa a if among the several phenomenon objective and nsubjective that made the sum total of the incident there had bee a nuncertai element which had diffused it dubious characte ove all had nleavened the whole mass with unreality did not like it nat the breakfast table the next morning there wa new face opposite nme sat young woma at whom merely glanced a took my seat i nspeaking to the high and mighty female personage who condescended to nseem to wait upo u this girl soo invited my attentio by the sound nof he voice which wa like yet not altogethe like the one still nmurmuring i my memory of the previous evening adventure moment nlate anothe girl few year olde entered the room and sat at the nleft of the othe speaking to he gentle good morning by _her_ nvoice wa startled it wa without doubt the one of which the first ngirl had reminded me here wa the lady of the sylva incident sitting nbodily before me i he habit a she lived nevidently enough the two were sister nwith nebulous kind of apprehensio that might be recognized a the nmute inglorious hero of a adventure which had i my consciousness and nconscience something of the characte of eavesdropping allowed myself nonly hasty cup of the lukewarm coffee thoughtfully provided by the nprescient waitress fo the emergency and left the table a passed nout of the house into the ground heard rich strong male voice nsinging a aria from rigoletto am bound to say that it wa nexquisitely sung too but there wa something i the performance that ndispleased me could say neithe what no why and walked rapidly naway nreturning late i the day saw the elde of the two young wome nstanding o the porch and nea he tall ma i black clothing the ma nwhom had expected to see all day the desire to know something of nthese person had bee uppermost i my mind and now resolved to lea nwhat could of them i any way that wa neithe dishonorable no low nthe ma wa talking easily and affably to his companio but at the nsound of my footstep o the gravel walk he ceased and turning about nlooked me full i the face he wa apparently of middle age dark and nuncommonly handsome his attire wa faultless his bearing easy and ngraceful the look which he turned upo me ope free and devoid of any nsuggestio of rudeness nevertheless it affected me with distinct nemotio which o subsequent analysis i memory appeared to be compounded nof hatred and dread am unwilling to call it fea second late the nma and woma had disappeared they seemed to have trick of ndisappearing o entering the house howeve saw them through the nope doorway of the parlo a passed they had merely stepped through na window which opened dow to the floo ncautiously approached o the subject of he new guest my landlady nproved not ungracious restated with hope some small reverence fo nenglish gramma the fact were these the two girl were pauline and eva nmaynard of sa francisco the elde wa pauline the ma wa richard nbenning thei guardia who had bee the most intimate friend of thei nfathe now deceased m benning had brought them to brownville i the nhope that the mountai climate might benefit eva who wa thought to be ni dange of consumptio nupo these short and simple annals the landlady wrought a embroidery of neulogium which abundantly attested he faith i m benning will and nability to pay fo the best that he house afforded that he had good nheart wa evident to he from his devotio to his two beautiful ward nand his really touching solicitude fo thei comfort the evidence nimpressed me a insufficient and silently found the scotch verdict not prove ncertainly m benning wa most attentive to his ward i my stroll nabout the country frequently encountered them sometimes i company nwith othe guest of the hotel exploring the gulch fishing rifle nshooting and otherwise wiling away the monotony of country life and nalthough watched them a closely a good manner would permit saw nnothing that would i any way explai the strange word that had noverheard i the wood had grow tolerably well acquainted with the nyoung lady and could exchange look and eve greeting with thei nguardia without actual repugnance na month went by and had almost ceased to interest myself i thei naffairs whe one night ou entire little community wa throw into nexcitement by a event which vividly recalled my experience i the nforest nthis wa the death of the elde girl pauline nthe sister had occupied the same bedroom o the third floo of the nhouse waking i the gray of the morning eva had found pauline dead nbeside he late whe the poo girl wa weeping beside the body amid nthrong of sympathetic if not very considerate person m benning nentered the room and appeared to be about to take he hand she drew naway from the side of the dead and moved slowly toward the doo it is you she said you who have done this you you you she is raving he said i low voice he followed he step by step na she retreated his eye fixed upo hers with steady gaze i which nthere wa nothing of tenderness no of compassio she stopped the hand nthat she had raised i accusatio fell to he side he dilated eye ncontracted visibly the lid slowly dropped ove them veiling thei nstrange wild beauty and she stood motionless and almost a white a the ndead girl lying nea the ma took he hand and put his arm gently about nhe shoulder a if to support he suddenly she burst into passio nof tear and clung to him a child to it mothe he smiled with nsmile that affected me most disagreeably perhaps any kind of smile nwould have done so and led he silently out of the room nthere wa a inquest and the customary verdict the deceased it nappeared came to he death through heart disease it wa before the ninventio of heart _failure_ though the heart of poo pauline had nindubitably failed the body wa embalmed and take to sa francisco by nsome one summoned thence fo the purpose neithe eva no benning naccompanying it some of the hotel gossip ventured to think that very nstrange and few hardy spirit went so fa a to think it very strange nindeed but the good landlady generously threw herself into the breach nsaying it wa owing to the precarious nature of the girl health it is nnot of record that eithe of the two person most affected and napparently least concerned made any explanatio none evening about week afte the death went out upo the veranda of nthe hotel
