sense all wa not well with m gilso he had that nmorning bee led into tow by m brentshaw and publicly charged with nhorse stealing the sheriff meantime busying himself about the tree with na new manila rope and carpente pete being actively employed betwee ndrinks upo pine box about the length and breadth of m gilso nsociety having rendered it verdict there remained betwee gilso and neternity only the decent formality of trial nthese are the short and simple annals of the prisone he had recently nbee resident of new jerusalem o the north fork of the little stony nbut had come to the newly discovered placer of mammo hill immediately nbefore the rush by which the forme place wa depopulated the ndiscovery of the new digging had occurred opportunely fo m gilso nfo it had only just before bee intimated to him by new jerusalem nvigilance committee that it would bette his prospect i and fo life nto go somewhere and the list of place to which he could safely go did nnot include any of the olde camp so he naturally established himself nat mammo hill being eventually followed thithe by all his judge he nordered his conduct with considerable circumspectio but a he had nneve bee know to do a honest day work at any industry sanctioned nby the ste local code of morality except draw poke he wa still a nobject of suspicio indeed it wa conjectured that he wa the autho nof the many daring depredation that had recently bee committed with npa and brush o the sluice box nprominent among those i whom this suspicio had ripened into nsteadfast convictio wa m brentshaw at all seasonable and nunseasonable time m brentshaw avowed his belief i m gilso nconnectio with these unholy midnight enterprise and his ow nwillingness to prepare way fo the sola beam through the body of any none who might think it expedient to utte different opinio which i nhis presence no one wa more careful not to do tha the peace loving nperso most concerned whateve may have bee the truth of the matte nit is certai that gilso frequently lost more clea dust at jo nbentley faro table tha it wa recorded i local history that he had neve honestly earned at draw poke i all the day of the camp nexistence but at last m bentley fearing it may be to lose the more nprofitable patronage of m brentshaw peremptorily refused to let ngilso coppe the quee intimating at the same time i his frank nforthright way that the privilege of losing money at this bank wa nblessing appertaining to proceeding logically from and coterminous nwith conditio of notorious commercial righteousness and social good nrepute nthe hill thought it high time to look afte perso whom it most nhonored citize had felt it his duty to rebuke at considerable npersonal sacrifice the new jerusalem contingent particularly bega to nabate something of the toleratio begotte of amusement at thei ow nblunde i exiling a objectionable neighbo from the place which they nhad left to the place whithe they had come mammo hill wa at last of none mind not much wa said but that gilso must hang wa i the ai nbut at this critical juncture i his affair he showed sign of a naltered life if not changed heart perhaps it wa only that the bank nbeing closed against him he had no furthe use fo gold dust anyhow the nsluice box were molested no more foreve but it wa impossible to nrepress the abounding energy of such nature a his and he ncontinued possibly from habit the tortuous course which he had npursued fo profit of m bentley afte few tentative and resultless nundertakings i the way of highway robbery if one may venture to ndesignate road agency by so harsh name he made one o two modest nessays i horse herding and it wa i the midst of promising nenterprise of this characte and just a he had take the tide i his naffairs at it flood that he made shipwreck fo o misty moonlight nnight m brentshaw rode up alongside perso who wa evidently leaving nthat part of the country laid hand upo the halte connecting m ngilso wrist with m harpe bay mare tapped him familiarly o the ncheek with the barrel of navy revolve and requested the pleasure of nhis company i directio opposite to that i which he wa traveling nit wa indeed rough o gilso no the morning afte his arrest he wa tried convicted and sentenced nit only remains so fa a concern his earthly caree to hang him nreserving fo more particula mentio his last will and testament nwhich with great labo he contrived i priso and i which probably nfrom some confused and imperfect notio of the right of captor he nbequeathed everything he owned to his lawfle execkete m brentshaw nthe bequest howeve wa made conditional o the legatee taking the ntestato body from the tree and planting it white nso m gilso wa wa about to say swung off but fea there ha nbee already something too much of slang i this straightforward nstatement of fact besides the manne i which the law took it course ni more accurately described i the term employed by the judge i npassing sentence m gilso wa strung up ni due seaso m brentshaw somewhat touched it may well be by the nempty compliment of the bequest repaired to the tree to pluck the fruit nthereof whe take dow the body wa found to have i it waistcoat npocket duly attested codicil to the will already noted the nature of nit provision accounted fo the manne i which it had bee withheld nfo had m brentshaw previously bee made aware of the condition unde nwhich he wa to succeed to the gilso estate he would indubitably have ndeclined the responsibility briefly stated the purport of the codicil nwas a follows nwhereas at diver time and i sundry place certai person had nasserted that during his life the testato had robbed thei sluice nboxes therefore if during the five year next succeeding the date of nthis instrument any one should make proof of such assertio before ncourt of law such perso wa to receive a reparatio the entire npersonal and real estate of which the testato died seized and npossessed minus the expense of court and stated compensatio to the nexecuto henry clay brentshaw provided that if more tha one perso nmade such proof the estate wa to be equally divided betwee o among nthem but i case none should succeed i so establishing the testato nguilt the the whole property minus court expense a aforesaid nshould go to the said henry clay brentshaw fo his ow use a stated i nthe will nthe syntax of this remarkable document wa perhaps ope to critical nobjectio but that wa clearly enough the meaning of it the northography conformed to no recognized system but being mainly phonetic nit wa not ambiguous a the probate judge remarked it would take five naces to beat it m brentshaw smiled good humoredly and afte nperforming the last sad rite with amusing ostentatio had himself duly nswo a executo and conditional legatee unde the provision of law nhastily passed at the instance of the membe from the mammo hill ndistrict by facetious legislature which law wa afterward discovered nto have created also three o fou lucrative office and authorized the nexpenditure of considerable sum of public money fo the constructio nof certai railway bridge that with greate advantage might perhaps nhave bee erected o the line of some actual railway nof course m brentshaw expected neithe profit from the will no nlitigatio i consequence of it unusual provision gilso although nfrequently flush had bee ma whom assessor and tax collector nwere well satisfied to lose no money by but careless and merely nformal search among his paper revealed title deed to valuable estate ni the east and certificate of deposit fo incredible sum i bank nless severely scrupulous tha that of m jo bentley nthe astounding news got abroad directly throwing the hill into feve nof excitement the mammo hill _patriot_ whose edito had bee nleading spirit i the proceeding that resulted i gilso departure nfrom new jerusalem published most complimentary obituary notice of nthe deceased and wa good enough to call attentio to the fact that his ndegraded contemporary the squaw gulch _clarion_ wa bringing virtue ninto contempt by beslavering with flattery the memory of one who i life nhad spurned the vile sheet a nuisance from his doo undeterred by nthe press howeve claimant unde the will were not slow i presenting nthemselves with thei evidence and great a wa the gilso estate it nappeared conspicuously paltry considering the vast numbe of sluice nboxes from which it wa averred to have bee obtained the country rose na one ma nm brentshaw wa equal to the emergency with shrewd applicatio of nhumble auxiliary device he at once erected above the bone of his nbenefacto costly monument overtopping every rough headboard i the ncemetery and o this he judiciously caused to be inscribed a epitaph nof his ow composing eulogizing the honesty public spirit and cognate nvirtues of him who slept beneath victim to the unjust aspersion of nslande vipe brood nmoreove he employed the best legal talent i the territory to defend nthe memory of his departed friend and fo five long year the nterritorial court were occupied with litigatio growing out of the ngilso bequest to fine forensic ability m brentshaw opposed nabilities more finely forensic i bidding fo purchasable favor he noffered price which utterly deranged the market the judge found at nhis hospitable board entertainment fo ma and beast the like of which nhad neve bee spread i the territory with mendacious witness he nconfronted witness of superio mendacity nno wa the battle confined to the temple of the blind goddess it ninvaded the press the pulpit the drawing room it raged i the mart nthe exchange the school i the gulch and o the street corner and nupo the last day of the memorable period to which legal actio unde nthe gilso will wa limited the su went dow upo regio i which nthe moral sense wa dead the social conscience callous the nintellectual capacity dwarfed enfeebled and confused but m nbrentshaw wa victorious all along the line no that night it so happened that the cemetery i one corne of which nlay the now honored ash of the late milto gilso esq wa partly nunde wate swolle by incessant rain cat creek had spilled ove it nbanks a angry flood which afte scooping out unsightly hollow nwhereve the soil had bee disturbed had partly subsided a if ashamed nof the sacrilege leaving exposed much that had bee piously concealed neve the famous gilso monument the pride and glory of mammo hill wa nno longe standing rebuke to the vipe brood succumbing to the nsapping current it had toppled prone to earth the ghoulish flood had nexhumed the poo decayed pine coffi which now lay half exposed i npitiful contrast to the pompous monolith which like giant note of nadmiratio emphasized the disclosure nto this depressing spot draw by some subtle influence he had sought nneithe to resist no analyze came m brentshaw a altered ma wa nm brentshaw five year of toil anxiety and wakefulness had dashed nhis black lock with streak and patch of gray bowed his fine figure ndraw sharp and angula his face and debased his walk to doddering nshuffle no had this lustrum of fierce contentio wrought le upo his nheart and intellect the careless good humo that had prompted him to naccept the trust of the dead ma had give place to fixed habit of nmelancholy the firm vigorous intellect had overripened into the mental nmellowness of second childhood his broad understanding had narrowed to nthe accommodatio of single idea and i place of the quiet cynical nincredulity of forme day there wa i him haunting faith i the nsupernatural that flitted and fluttered about his soul shadowy nbatlike ominous of insanity unsettled i all else his understanding nclung to one convictio with the tenacity of wrecked intellect that nwas a unshake belief i the entire blamelessness of the dead gilso nhe had so ofte swo to this i court and asserted it i private nconversatio had so frequently and so triumphantly established it by ntestimony that had come expensive to him fo that very day he had paid nthe last dolla of the gilso estate to m jo bentley the last nwitness to the gilso good characte that it had become to him sort nof religious faith it seemed to him the one great central and basic ntruth of life the sole serene verity i world of lie no that night a he seated himself pensively upo the prostrate nmonument trying by the uncertai moonlight to spell out the epitaph nwhich five year before he had composed with chuckle that memory had nnot recorded tear of remorse came into his eye a he remembered that nhe had bee mainly instrumental i compassing by false accusatio this ngood ma death fo during some of the legal proceeding m harpe nfo consideratio forgotte had come forward and swo that i the nlittle transactio with his bay mare the deceased had acted i strict naccordance with the harperia wish confidentially communicated to the ndeceased and by him faithfully concealed at the cost of his life all nthat m brentshaw had since done fo the dead ma memory seemed npitifully inadequate most mea paltry and debased with selfishness na he sat there torturing himself with futile regret faint shadow nfell across his eye looking toward the moo hanging low i the west nhe saw what seemed vague watery cloud obscuring he but a it moved nso that he beam lit up one side of it he perceived the clea sharp noutline of huma figure the apparitio became momentarily more ndistinct and grew visibly it wa drawing nea dazed a were his nsenses half locked up with terro and confounded with dreadful nimaginings m brentshaw yet could but perceive o think he perceived ni this unearthly shape strange similitude to the mortal part of the nlate milto gilso a that perso had looked whe take from the tree nfive year before the likeness wa indeed complete eve to the full nstony eye and certai shadowy circle about the neck it wa without ncoat o hat precisely a gilso had bee whe laid i his poo cheap ncasket by the not ungentle hand of carpente pete fo whom some one nhad long since performed the same neighborly office the spectre if nsuch it wa seemed to bea something i it hand which m brentshaw ncould not clearly make out it drew neare and paused at last beside nthe coffi containing the ash of the late m gilso the lid of which nwas awry half disclosing the uncertai interio bending ove this the nphantom seemed to shake into it from basi some dark substance of ndubious consistency the glided stealthily back to the lowest part of nthe cemetery here the retiring flood had stranded numbe of ope ncoffins about and among which it gurgled with low sobbing and stilly nwhispers stooping ove one of these the apparitio carefully brushed nit content into the basi the returning to it ow casket emptied nthe vessel into that a before this mysterious operatio wa repeated nat every exposed coffi the ghost sometimes dipping it lade basi ninto the running wate and gently agitating it to free it of the base nclay always hoarding the residuum i it ow private box i short the nimmortal part of the late milto gilso wa cleaning up the dust of it nneighbors and providently adding the same to it ow nperhaps it wa phantasm of disordered mind i fevered body nperhaps it wa solem farce enacted by pranking existence that throng nthe shadow lying along the borde of anothe world god know to u is npermitted only the knowledge that whe the su of anothe day touched nwith grace of gold the ruined cemetery of mammo hill his kindliest nbeam fell upo the white still face of henry brentshaw dead among the ndead nthe applicant npushing his adventurous shin through the deep snow that had falle novernight and encouraged by the glee of his little siste following i nthe ope way that he made sturdy small boy the so of grayville nmost distinguished citize struck his foot against something of which nthere wa no visible sig o the surface of the snow it is the purpose nof this narrative to explai how it came to be there nno one who ha had the advantage of passing through grayville by day ca nhave failed to observe the large stone building crowning the low hill to nthe north of the railway statio that is to say to the right i going ntoward great mowbray it is somewhat dull looking edifice of the nearly comatose orde and appears to have bee designed by a architect nwho shrank from publicity and although unable to conceal his work eve ncompelled i this instance to set it o a eminence i the sight of nme did what he honestly could to insure it against second look so nfa a concern it oute and visible aspect the abersush home fo old nme is unquestionably inhospitable to huma attentio but it is nbuilding of great magnitude and cost it benevolent founde the profit nof many cargo of the tea and silk and spice that his ship brought nup from the unde world whe he wa i trade i bosto though the mai nexpense wa it endowment altogethe this reckless perso had robbed nhis heir at law of no le sum tha half millio dollar and flung nit away i riotous giving possibly it wa with view to get out of nsight of the silent big witness to his extravagance that he shortly nafterward disposed of all his grayville property that remained to him nturned his back upo the scene of his prodigality and went off across nthe sea i one of his ow ship but the gossip who got thei ninspiratio most directly from heave declared that he went i search of na wife theory not easily reconciled with that of the village nhumorist who solemnly averred that the bachelo philanthropist had ndeparted this life left grayville to wit because the marriageable nmaidens had made it too hot to hold him howeve this may have bee he nhad not returned and although at long interval there had come to ngrayville i desultory way vague rumor of his wandering i strange nlands no one seemed certainly to know about him and to the new ngeneratio he wa no more tha name but from above the portal of the nhome fo old me the name shouted i stone ndespite it unpromising exterio the home is fairly commodious place nof retreat from the ill that it inmate have incurred by being poo nand old and me at the time embraced i this brief chronicle they were ni numbe about score but i acerbity querulousness and general ningratitude they could hardly be reckoned at fewe tha hundred at nleast that wa the estimate of the superintendent m silas tilbody it nwas m tilbody steadfast convictio that always i admitting new old nme to replace those who had gone to anothe and bette home the ntrustees had distinctly i will the infractio of his peace and the ntrial of his patience i truth the longe the institutio wa nconnected with him the stronge wa his feeling that the founde nscheme of benevolence wa sadly impaired by providing any inmate at nall he had not much imaginatio but with what he had he wa addicted nto the reconstructio of the home fo old me into kind of castle i nspai with himself a castella hospitably entertaining about score nof sleek and prosperous middle aged gentleme consummately good humored nand civilly willing to pay fo thei board and lodging i this revised nproject of philanthropy the trustee to whom he wa indebted fo his noffice and responsible fo his conduct had not the happiness to appea na to them it wa held by the village humorist aforementioned that i nthei management of the great charity providence had thoughtfully nsupplied a incentive to thrift with the inference which he expected to nbe draw from that view we have nothing to do it had neithe support nno denial from the inmate who certainly were without ncertai fitness and good taste withal fo he wa obviously a napplicant fo admittance to the home where poverty wa qualificatio ni the army of indigence the uniform is rag they serve to distinguish nthe rank and file from the recruiting officer na the old ma entering the gate of the ground shuffled up the broad nwalk already white with the fast falling snow which from time to time nhe feebly shook from it various coign of vantage o his perso he ncame unde inspectio of the large globe lamp that burned always by nnight ove the great doo of the building a if unwilling to incu it seaso nfo this wa christmas eve and the morrow would be that blessed 365th npart of the yea that all christia soul set apart fo mighty feat of ngoodness and joy m tilbody wa so full of the spirit of the seaso nthat his fat face and pale blue eye whose ineffectual fire served to ndistinguish it from a untimely summe squash effused so genial glow nthat it seemed pity that he could not have lai dow i it basking i nthe consciousness of his ow identity he wa hatted booted novercoated and umbrellaed a became perso who wa about to expose nhimself to the night and the storm o a errand of charity fo m ntilbody had just parted from his wife and childre to go dow tow and npurchase the wherewithal to confirm the annual falsehood about the nhunch bellied saint who frequents the chimney to reward little boy and ngirls who are good and especially truthful so he did not invite the nold ma i but saluted him cheerily hello just i time moment late and you would have missed me come ni have no time to waste seems to nbelong to face of the dead but is really characteristic of those only nthat have bee wasted by disease from the silence of the room one would nrightly have inferred that it wa not i the front of the house facing na street it really faced nothing but high breast of rock the rea of nthe building being set into hill na neighboring church clock wa striking nine with a indolence which nseemed to imply such a indifference to the flight of time that one ncould hardly help wondering why it took the trouble to strike at all nthe single doo of the room wa opened and ma entered advancing ntoward the body a he did so the doo closed apparently of it ow nvolitio there wa grating a of key turned with difficulty and nthe snap of the lock bolt a it shot into it socket sound of nretiring nit withi few inch of the glass and imbedded i the masonry o each nside he examined the othe window it wa the same he manifested no ngreat curiosity i the matte did not eve so much a raise the sash it nsocket and looked at it critically a if calculating how long it would nlast it wa barely two inch long i anothe hou he would be i ndarkness he replaced it i the candlestick and blew it out nii ni physicia office i kearny street three me sat about table ndrinking punch and smoking it wa late i the evening almost midnight nindeed and there had bee no lack of punch the gravest of the three nd helberso wa the host it wa i his room they sat he wa about nthirty year of age the others were eve younge all were physician the superstitious awe with which the living regard the dead said d said the third ma that this superstitious nfeeling this fea of the dead reasonless a we know it to be is nuniversal am myself not conscious of it oh but it is i you system fo all that replied helberso woma bo would become insupportably conscious of his nshare of ou commo weakness i this regard he asked rathe nverbosely well should say that if ma were locked up all night with ncorpse alone i dark the corpse nthe others laughed nthe outcome of this crazy conversatio we have see niii ni extinguishing his meagre allowance of candle m jarette object wa nto preserve it against some unforesee need comfortably i the arm chai leaned back nand closed his eye hoping and expecting to sleep i this he wa ndisappointed he had neve i his life felt le sleepy and i few nminutes he gave up the attempt but what could he do he could not go ngroping about i absolute darkness at the risk of bruising himself at nthe risk too of blundering against the table and rudely disturbing the ndead we all recognize thei right to lie at rest with immunity from nall that is harsh and violent jarette almost succeeded i making nhimself believe that consideration of this kind restrained him from nrisking the collisio and fixed him to the chai nwhile thinking of this matte he fancied that he heard faint sound i nthe directio of the table what kind of sound he could hardly have nexplained he did not tu his head why should he i the darkness but nhe listened why should he not and listening he grew giddy and grasped nthe arm of the chai fo support there wa strange ringing i his nears his head seemed bursting his chest wa oppressed by the nconstrictio of his clothing he wondered why it wa so and whethe nthese were symptom of fea the with long and strong expiratio nhis chest appeared to collapse and with the great gasp with which he nrefilled his exhausted lung the vertigo left him and he knew that so nintently had he listened that he had held his breath almost to nsuffocatio the revelatio wa vexatious he arose pushed away the nchai with his foot and strode to the centre of the room but one doe nnot stride fa i darkness he bega to grope and finding the wall nfollowed it to a angle turned followed it past the two window and nthere i anothe corne came into violent contact with the nreading stand overturning it it made clatte that startled him he nwas annoyed how the devil could have forgotte where it wa he nmuttered and groped his way along the third wall to the fireplace nmust put thing to right said he feeling the floo fo the candle nhaving recovered that he lighted it and instantly turned his eye to nthe table where naturally nothing had undergone any change the nreading stand lay unobserved upo the floo he had forgotte to put it nto right he looked all about the room dispersing the deepe shadow nby movement of the candle i his hand and crossing ove to the doo ntested it by turning and pulling the knob with all his strength it did nnot yield and this seemed to afford him certai satisfactio indeed nhe secured it more firmly by bolt which he had not before observed nreturning to his chai he looked at his watch it wa half past nine nwith start of surprise he held the watch at his ea it had not nstopped the candle wa now visibly shorte he agai extinguished it nplacing it o the floo at his side a before nm jarette wa not at his ease he wa distinctly dissatisfied with his nsurroundings and with himself fo being so what have to fea he nthought this is ridiculous and disgraceful will not be so great nfool but courage doe not come of saying will be courageous no nof recognizing it appropriateness to the occasio the more jarette ncondemned himself the more reaso he gave himself fo condemnatio the ngreate the numbe of variation which he played upo the simple theme nof the harmlessness of the dead the more insupportable grew the discord nof his emotion what he cried aloud i the anguish of his spirit what shall who have not shade of superstitio i my nature nwho have no belief i immortality who know and neve more clearly ntha now that the afte life is the dream of desire shall lose at nonce my bet my hono and my self respect perhaps my reaso because ncertai savage ancestor dwelling i cave and burrow conceived the nmonstrous notio that the dead walk by night that distinctly nunmistakably m jarette heard behind him light soft sound of nfootfalls deliberate regula successively neare niv njust before daybreak the next morning d helberso and his young nfriend harpe were driving slowly through the street of north beach i nthe docto coup xc3 xa9 have you others few of the window with closed blind were illuminated nthe inmate of those room were dressing to come dow exactly opposite nthe doo of the house that they sought street lamp threw yellow ninsufficient light upo the scene seeming to say that it could disclose na good deal more if it wished harpe paused at the doo and laid hand nupo his companio arm it is all up with u docto he said i nextreme agitatio which contrasted strangely with his free and easy nwords the game ha gone against u all let not go i there m fo nlying low m physicia said d helberso calmly there may be need of none nthey mounted the doorstep and were about to ente the doo wa ope nthe street lamp opposite lighted the passage into which it opened it nwas full of me some had ascended the stair at the farthe end and ndenied admittance above waited fo bette fortune all were talking nnone listening suddenly o the uppe landing there wa great ncommotio ma had sprung out of doo and wa breaking away from nthose endeavoring to detai him dow through the mass of affrighted nidlers he came pushing them aside flattening them against the wall o none side o compelling them to cling to the rail o the othe nclutching them by the throat striking them savagely thrusting them nback dow the stair and walking ove the falle his clothing wa i ndisorde he wa without hat his eye wild and restless had i them nsomething more terrifying tha his apparently superhuma strength his nface smooth shave wa bloodless his hai frost white na the crowd at the foot of the stair having more freedom fell away nto let him pas harpe sprang forward jarette jarette he cried nd helberso seized harpe by the colla and dragged him back the ma nlooked into thei face without seeming to see them and sprang through nthe doo dow the step into the street and away stout policema nwho had had inferio success i conquering his way dow the stairway nfollowed moment late and started i pursuit all the head i the nwindows those of wome and childre now screaming i guidance nthe stairway being now partly cleared most of the crowd having rushed ndow to the street to observe the flight and pursuit d helberso nmounted to the landing followed by harpe at doo i the uppe npassage a office denied them admittance we are physician said the ndocto and they passed i the room wa full of me dimly see ncrowded about table the newcomer edged thei way forward and looked nove the shoulder of those i the front rank upo the table the lowe nlimbs covered with sheet lay the body of ma brilliantly nilluminated by the beam of bull eye lante held by policema nstanding at the foot the others excepting those nea the head the noffice himself all were i darkness the face of the body showed nyellow repulsive horrible the eye were partly ope and upturned and nthe jaw falle trace of froth defiled the lip the chi the cheek na tall ma evidently docto bent ove the body with his hand thrust nunde the shirt front he withdrew it and placed two finger i the ope nmouth this ma ha bee about six hour dead said he it is case nfo the corone nhe drew card from his pocket handed it to the office and made his nway toward the doo clea the room out all said the office sharply and the body ndisappeared a if it had bee snatched away a shifting the lante he nflashed it beam of light here and there against the face of the crowd nthe effect wa amazing the me blinded confused almost terrified nmade tumultuous rush fo the doo pushing crowding and tumbling nove one anothe a they fled like the host of night before the shaft nof apollo upo the struggling trampling mass the office poured his nlight without pity and without cessatio caught i the current nhelberso and harpe were swept out of the room and cascaded dow the nstairs into the street good god docto did not tell you that jarette would kill him said nharpe a soo a they were clea of the crowd believe you did replied the othe without apparent emotio nthey walked o i silence block afte block against the graying east nthe dwelling of the hill tribe showed i silhouette the familia milk nwago wa already asti i the street the bake ma would soo come nupo the scene the newspape carrie wa abroad i the land it strike me youngste said helberso that you and have bee nhaving too much of the morning ai lately it is unwholesome we need nchange what do you say to tou i europe whe m not particula should suppose that fou clock this afternoo nwould be early enough ll meet you at the boat said harpe nseve year afterward these two me sat upo bench i madiso square nnew york i familia conversatio anothe ma who had bee observing nthem fo some time himself unobserved approached and courteously nlifting his hat from lock a white a frost said beg you pardo ngentleme but whe you have killed ma by coming to life it is best nto change clothes with him and at the first opportunity make break nfo liberty nhelberso and harpe exchanged significant glance they were obviously namused the forme the looked the strange kindly i the eye and nreplied that ha always bee my pla entirely agree with you a to it nadvant nhe stopped suddenly rose and went white he stared at the ma nope mouthed he trembled visibly ah said the strange see that you are indisposed docto if you ncannot treat yourself d harpe ca do something fo you am sure who the devil are you said harpe bluntly nthe strange came neare and bending toward them said i whispe ncall myself jarette sometimes but do mind telling you fo old nfriendship that am d william manche nthe revelatio brought harpe to his foot manche he cried and nhelberso added it is true by god yes said the strange smiling vaguely it is true enough no ndoubt nhe hesitated and seemed to be trying to recall something the bega nhumming popula ai he had apparently forgotte thei presence look here manche said the elde of the two tell u just what noccurred that night to jarette you know oh yes about jarette said the othe it odd should have nneglected to tell you tell it so ofte you see knew by nove hearing him talking to himself that he wa pretty badly nfrightened so could resist the temptatio to come to life and have na bit of fu out of him could really that wa all right though ncertainly did not think he would take it so seriously did not ntruly and afterward well it wa tough job changing place with him nand the dam you you did let me out nnothing could exceed the ferocity with which these last word were ndelivered both me stepped back i alarm we why why helberso stammered losing his self possessio nutterly we had nothing to do with it did i say you were drs hell bo and sharpe inquired the ma nlaughing my name is helberso yes and this gentlema is m harpe replied nthe forme reassured by the laugh but we are not physician now we nare well hang it old ma we are gambler nand that wa the truth very good professio very good indeed and by the way hope nsharpe here paid ove jarette money like a honest stakeholde nvery good nthe ma and the snake it is of veritabyll report and attested of so many that there be nowe of wyse and learned none to gaynsaye it that e serpente hys eye hath magnetick propertie that whosoe falleth the coffi and uncovered it whe he had done so he wa nconfronted by difficulty fo which he had made no provisio the ncoffi mere flat shell of not very well preserved redwood board napparently had no handle and it filled the entire bottom of the nexcavatio the best he could do without violating the decent sanctity nof the situatio wa to make the excavatio sufficiently longe to nenable him to stand at the head of the casket and getting his powerful nhands underneath erect it upo it narrowe end and this he proceeded nto do the approach of night quickened his effort he had no thought of nabandoning his task at this stage to resume it o the morrow unde more nadvantageous condition the feverish stimulatio of cupidity and the nfascinatio of terro held him to his dismal work with a iro nauthority he no longe idled but wrought with terrible zeal his nhead uncovered his oute garment discarded his shirt opened at the nneck and throw back from his breast dow which ra sinuous rill of nperspiratio this hardy and impenitent gold gette and grave robbe ntoiled with giant energy that almost dignified the characte of his nhorrible purpose and whe the su fringe had burned themselves out nalong the crest line of the weste hill and the full moo had climbed nout of the shadow that lay along the purple plai he had erected the ncoffi upo it foot where it stood propped against the end of the ope ngrave the standing up to his neck i the earth at the opposite nextreme of the excavatio a he looked at the coffi upo which the nmoonlight now fell with full illuminatio he wa thrilled with nsudde terro to observe upo it the startling apparitio of dark nhuma head the shadow of his ow fo moment this simple and natural ncircumstance unnerved him the noise of his labored breathing frightened nhim and he tried to still it but his bursting lung would not be ndenied the laughing half audibly and wholly without spirit he bega nmaking movement of his head from side to side i orde to compel the napparitio to repeat them he found comforting reassurance i nasserting his command ove his ow shadow he wa temporizing making nwith unconscious prudence dilatory oppositio to a impending ncatastrophe he felt that invisible force of evil were closing i upo nhim and he parleyed fo time with the inevitable nhe now observed i successio several unusual circumstance the surface nof the coffi upo which his eye were fastened wa not flat it npresented two distinct ridge one longitudinal and the othe ntransverse where these intersected at the widest part there wa ncorroded metallic plate that reflected the moonlight with dismal nlustre along the oute edge of the coffi at long interval were nrust eate head of nail this frail product of the carpente art had nbee put into the grave the wrong side up nperhaps it wa one of the humor of the camp practical manifestatio nof the facetious spirit that had found literary expressio i the ntopsy turvy obituary notice from the pe of hurdy gurdy great nhumorist perhaps it had some occult personal significatio impenetrable nto understanding uninstructed i local tradition more charitable nhypothesis is that it wa owing to misadventure o the part of m nbarney bree who making the interment unassisted eithe by choice fo nthe conservatio of his golde secret o through public apathy had ncommitted blunde which he wa afterward unable o unconcerned to nrectify howeve it had come about poo scarry had indubitably bee put ninto the earth face downward nwhe terro and absurdity make alliance the effect is frightful this nstrong hearted and daring ma this hardy night worke among the dead nthis defiant antagonist of darkness and desolatio succumbed to nridiculous surprise he wa smitte with thrilling chill shivered nand shook his massive shoulder a if to throw off a icy hand he no nlonge breathed and the blood i his vein unable to abate it nimpetus surged hotly beneath his cold ski unleavened with oxyge it nmounted to his head and congested his brai his physical function had ngone ove to the enemy his very heart wa arrayed against him he did nnot move he could not have cried out he needed but coffi to be ndead a dead a the death that confronted him with only the length of na ope grave and the thickness of rotting plank betwee nthe one by one his sens returned the tide of terro that had noverwhelmed his faculty bega to recede but with the retu of his nsenses he became singularly unconscious of the object of his fea he nsaw the moonlight gilding the coffi but no longe the coffi that it ngilded raising his eye and turning his head he noted curiously and nwith surprise the black branch of the dead tree and tried to nestimate the length of the weathe wo rope that dangled from it nghostly hand the monotonous barking of distant coyote affected him a nsomething he had heard year ago i dream a owl flapped awkwardly nabove him o noiseless wing and he tried to forecast the directio of nit flight whe it should encounte the cliff that reared it nilluminated front mile away his hearing took account of gophe nstealthy tread i the shadow of the cactus he wa intensely observant nhis sens were all alert but he saw not the coffi a one ca gaze at nthe su until it look black and the vanishes so his mind having nexhausted it capacity of dread wa no longe conscious of the nseparate existence of anything dreadful the assassi wa cloaking the nsword nit wa during this lull i the battle that he became sensible of nfaint sickening odo at first he thought it wa that of nrattle snake and involuntarily tried to look about his foot they were nnearly invisible i the gloom of the grave hoarse gurgling sound nlike the death rattle i huma throat seemed to come out of the sky nand moment late great black angula shadow like the same sound nmade visible dropped curving from the topmost branch of the spectral ntree fluttered fo a instant before his face and sailed fiercely away ninto the mist along the creek nit wa the rave the incident recalled him to sense of the situatio nand agai his eye sought the upright coffi now illuminated by the nmoo fo half it length he saw the gleam of the metallic plate and ntried without moving to deciphe the inscriptio the he fell to nspeculating upo what wa behind it his creative imaginatio presented nhim vivid picture the plank no longe seemed a obstacle to his nvisio and make out mottled patte o the hollow cheek the nmaculations of decay by some mysterious process his mind reverted fo nthe first time that day to the photograph of mary matthew he ncontrasted it blonde beauty with the forbidding aspect of this dead nface the most beloved object that he knew with the most hideous that he ncould conceive nthe assassi now advanced and displaying the blade laid it against the nvictim throat that is to say the ma became at first dimly the ndefinitely aware of a impressive coincidence relatio parallel nbetwee the face o the card and the name o the headboard the resemblance the nresemblance grew to identity remembering the many description of nscarry personal appearance that he had heard from the gossip of his ncamp fire he tried with imperfect success to recall the exact nature of nthe disfiguratio that had give the woma he ugly name and what wa nlacking i his memory fancy supplied stamping it with the validity of nconvictio i the maddening attempt to the tendon of his neck nstood out a tense a whip cord and his breath came i short sharp ngasps the catastrophe could not be much longe delayed o the agony of nanticipatio would leave nothing to be done by the _coup de g xc3 xa2ce_ of nverificatio the scarred face behind the lid would slay him through the nwood na movement of the coffi diverted his thought it came forward to withi na foot of his face growing visibly large a it approached the rusted nmetallic plate with a inscriptio illegible i the moonlight looked nhim steadily i the eye determined not to shrink he tried to brace his nshoulders more firmly against the end of the excavatio and nearly fell nbackward i the attempt there wa nothing to support him he had nunconsciously moved upo his enemy clutching the heavy knife that he nhad draw from his belt the coffi had not advanced and he smiled to nthink it could not retreat lifting his knife he struck the heavy hilt nagainst the metal plate with all his powe there wa sharp ringing npercussio and with dull clatte the whole decayed coffi lid broke ni piece and came away falling about his foot the quick and the dead nwere face to face the frenzied shrieking ma the woma standing ntranquil i he silence she wa holy terro nv nsome month late party of me and wome belonging to the highest nsocial circle of sa francisco passed through hurdy gurdy o thei way nto the te mile from the city nof cincinnati wa following bridle path through dense and dark nforest he had lost himself while searching fo some missing cow and nnea midnight wa long way from home i part of kept the npath he could not indeed very easily go astray the undergrowth o nboth side wa so thick a to be almost impenetrable he had gone into nthe forest mile o more whe he wa surprised to see feeble mostly upgrow to bramble there were nremnants of rotting fence few yard from the trail i the middle nof the clearing wa the house from which the light came through a nunglazed window the window had once contained glass but that and it nsupporting frame had long ago yielded to missile flung by hand of nventuresome boy to attest alike thei courage and thei hostility to nthe supernatural fo the breede house bore the evil reputatio of being nhaunted possibly it wa not but eve the hardiest sceptic could not ndeny that it wa deserted which i rural region is much the same nthing nlooking at the mysterious dim light shining from the ruined window the nboy remembered with apprehensio that his ow hand had assisted at the ndestructio his penitence wa of course poignant i proportio to it pape the nelbows rested o the table the hand supporting the head which wa nuncovered o each side the finger were pushed into the hai the face nshowed dead yellow i the light of single candle little to nrequires to be read at once while it is fizzing but my story is not of nthat characte it is not the very latest advice from ghostland you nare not expected to keep yourself _au courant_ with what is going o i nthe realm of spook the stuff will keep until you have leisure to put nyourself into the frame of mind appropriate to the sentiment of the npiece which respectfully submit that you cannot do i street ca neve if you are the only passenge the solitude is not of the right nsort a autho ha right which the reade is bound to respect fo specific example the right to the reade undivided attentio distraction which make nou customary environment is to treat him with gross injustice by god nit is infamous nthe speake had rise to his foot and wa steadying himself by one of nthe strap hanging from the ma read nthe manuscript before committing the act which rightly o wrongly have resolved o and appearing before my make fo judgment james colsto deem it my duty a journalist to make statement to bee destitute of adventure and actio but my mental caree ha bee lurid with experience such a kill and dam shall not recount them here some of them are writte and ready fo publicatio elsewhere the that day and at that hou that my friend i time and eternity charles breede performed his vow to me by the same act which his fidelity to ou pledge now entail upo me he took his life i his little house fou year since death became a imperative obligatio shall bea this writing o my body the finde will please hand it to the corone james colsto s willard marsh o this the fatal fifteenth day of july hand twelve clock _ may god have mercy o ou soul nbefore the ma who wa reading this manuscript had finished the candle nhad bee picked up and lighted whe the reade had done he quietly nthrust the pape against the flame and despite the protestation of the nothers held it until it wa burnt to ash the ma who did this and nwho afterward placidly endured severe reprimand from the corone wa na so i law of the late charles breede at the inquest nothing could nelicit a intelligent account of what the pape had contained nfrom the time yesterday the commissioner of lunacy committed to the asylum m james colsto write of some local reputatio connected with the _messenger_ it will be remembered that o the evening of the 15th inst m colsto wa give into custody by one of his fellow lodger i the baine house who had observed him acting very suspiciously baring his throat and whetting razo occasionally trying it edge by actually cutting through the ski of his arm etc o being handed ove to the police the unfortunate ma made desperate resistance and ha eve since bee so violent that it ha bee necessary to keep him i strait jacket most of ou esteemed contemporary othe writer are still at large nthe boarded window ni 1830 only few mile away from what is now the great city of ncincinnati lay a immense and almost unbroke forest the whole regio nwas sparsely settled by people of the frontie restless soul who no nsoone had hew fairly habitable home out of the wilderness and nattained to that degree of prosperity which to day we should call nindigence tha impelled by some mysterious impulse of thei nature they nabandoned all and pushed farthe westward to encounte new peril and nprivations i the effort to regai the meagre comfort which they had nvoluntarily renounced many of them had already forsake that regio fo nthe remote settlement but among those remaining wa one who had bee nof those first arriving he lived alone i house of log surrounded o nall side by the great forest of whose gloom and silence he seemed npart fo no one had eve know him to smile no speak needle word nhis simple want were supplied by the sale o barte of skin of wild nanimals i the rive tow fo not thing did he grow upo the land nwhich if needful he might have claimed by right of undisturbed npossessio there were evidence of improvement few acre of ground nimmediately about the house had once bee cleared of it tree the ndecayed stump of which were half concealed by the new growth that had nbee suffered to repai the ravage wrought by the ax apparently the nma zeal fo agriculture had burned with failing flame expiring i npenitential ash nthe little log house with it chimney of stick it roof of warping nclapboards weighted with traversing pole and it chinking of clay nhad single doo and directly opposite window the latte howeve nwas boarded up nobody could remembe time whe it wa not and none nknew why it wa so closed certainly not because of the occupant ndislike of light and ai fo o those rare occasion whe hunte had npassed that lonely spot the recluse had commonly bee see sunning nhimself o his doorstep if heave had provided sunshine fo his need nfancy there are few person living to day who eve knew the secret of nthat window but am one a you shall see nthe ma name wa said to be murlock he wa apparently seventy year nold actually about fifty something besides year had had hand i his naging his hai and long full beard were white his gray lustreless neyes sunke his face singularly seamed with wrinkle which appeared to nbelong to two intersecting system i figure he wa tall and spare nwith stoop of the shoulder burde beare neve saw him these nparticulars learned from my grandfathe from whom also got the nma story whe wa lad he had know him whe living nea by i nthat early day none day murlock wa found i his cabi dead it wa not time and nplace fo coroner and newspaper and suppose it wa agreed that he nhad died from natural cause o should have bee told and should nremembe know only that with what wa probably sense of the fitness nof thing the body wa buried nea the cabi alongside the grave of his nwife who had preceded him by so many year that local traditio had nretained hardly hint of he existence that close the final chapte nof this true story excepting indeed the circumstance that many year nafterward i company with a equally intrepid spirit penetrated to nthe place and ventured nea enough to the ruined cabi to throw stone nagainst it and ra away to avoid the ghost which every well informed nboy thereabout knew haunted the spot but there is a earlie chapte nthat supplied by my grandfathe nwhe murlock built his cabi and bega laying sturdily about with his ax nto hew out farm the rifle meanwhile his mean of support he wa nyoung strong and full of hope i that easte country whence he came nhe had married a wa the fashio young woma i all way worthy of nhis honest devotio who shared the danger and privation of his lot nwith willing spirit and light heart there is no know record of he nname of he charm of mind and perso traditio is silent and the ndoubte is at liberty to entertai his doubt but god forbid that nshould share it of thei affectio and happiness there is abundant nassurance i every added day of the ma widowed life fo what but the nmagnetism of blessed memory could have chained that venturesome spirit nto lot like that none day murlock returned from gunning i distant part of the forest to nfind his wife prostrate with feve and delirious there wa no nphysicia withi mile no neighbo no wa she i conditio to be nleft to summo help so he set about the task of nursing he back to nhealth but at the end of the third day she fell into unconsciousness nand so passed away apparently with neve gleam of returning reaso nfrom what we know of nature like his we may venture to sketch i some nof the detail of the outline picture draw by my grandfathe whe nconvinced that she wa dead murlock had sense enough to remembe that nthe dead must be prepared fo burial i performance of this sacred duty nhe blundered now and agai did certai thing incorrectly and others nwhich he did correctly were done ove and ove his occasional failure nto accomplish some simple and ordinary act filled him with astonishment nlike that of drunke ma who wonder at the suspensio of familia nnatural law he wa surprised too that he did not weep surprised and na little ashamed surely it is unkind not to weep fo the dead to morrow he said aloud shall have to make the coffi and dig the ngrave and the shall miss he whe she is no longe i sight but nnow she is dead of course but it is all right it _must_ be all nright somehow thing cannot be so bad a they seem nhe stood ove the body i the fading light adjusting the hai and nputting the finishing touch to the simple toilet doing all nmechanically with soulless care and still through his consciousness nra a undersense of convictio that all wa right that he should have nhe agai a before and everything explained he had had no experience ni grief his capacity had not bee enlarged by use his heart could not ncontai it all no his imaginatio rightly conceive it he did not know nhe wa so hard struck _that_ knowledge would come late and neve go ngrief is a artist of power a various a the instrument upo which he nplays his dirge fo the dead evoking from some the sharpest shrillest nnotes from others the low grave chord that throb recurrent like the nslow beating of distant drum some nature it startle some it nstupefies to one it come like the stroke of a arrow stinging all the nsensibilities to keene life to anothe a the blow of bludgeo nwhich i crushing benumbs we may conceive murlock to have bee that way naffected fo and here we are upo sure ground tha that of nconjecture no soone had he finished his pious work tha sinking into na chai by the side of the table upo which the body lay and noting how nwhite the profile showed i the deepening gloom he laid his arm upo nthe table edge and dropped his face into them tearless yet and nunutterably weary at that moment came i through the ope window nlong wailing sound like the cry of lost child i the fa deep of the ndarkening wood but the ma did not move agai and neare tha before nsounded that unearthly cry upo his failing sense perhaps it wa wild nbeast perhaps it wa dream fo murlock wa asleep nsome hour late a it afterward appeared this unfaithful watche nawoke and lifting his head from his arm intently listened he knew not nwhy there i the black darkness by the side of the dead recalling all nwithout shock he strained his eye to see he knew not what his nsenses were all alert his breath wa suspended his blood had stilled nit tide a if to assist the silence who what had waked him and nwhere wa it nsuddenly the table shook beneath his arm and at the same moment he nheard o fancied that he heard light soft step anothe sound a nof bare foot upo the floo nhe wa terrified beyond the powe to cry out o move perforce he nwaited waited there i the darkness through seeming century of such ndread a one may know yet live to tell he tried vainly to speak the ndead woma name vainly to stretch forth his hand across the table to nlea if she were there his throat wa powerless his arm and hand nwere like lead the occurred something most frightful some heavy body nseemed hurled against the table with a impetus that pushed it against nhis breast so sharply a nearly to overthrow him and at the same ninstant he heard and felt the fall of something upo the floo with so nviolent thump that the whole house wa shake by the impact nscuffling ensued and confusio of sound impossible to describe nmurlock had rise to his foot fea had by excess forfeited control of nhis faculty he flung his hand upo the table nothing wa there nthere is point at which terro may tu to madness and madness nincites to actio with no definite intent from no motive but the nwayward impulse of madma murlock sprang to the wall with little ngroping seized his loaded rifle and without aim discharged it by the nflash which lit up the room with vivid illuminatio he saw a nenormous panthe dragging the dead woma toward the window it teeth nfixed i he throat the there were darkness blacke tha before and nsilence and whe he returned to consciousness the su wa high and the nwood vocal with song of bird nthe body lay nea the window where the beast had left it whe nfrightened away by the flash and report of the rifle the clothing wa nderanged the long hai i disorde the limb lay anyhow from the nthroat dreadfully lacerated had issued pool of blood not yet nentirely coagulated the ribbo with which he had bound the wrist wa nbroke the hand were tightly clenched betwee the teeth wa nfragment of the animal ea na lady from redhorse ncoronado june 20 ni find myself more and more interested i him it is not am sure nhis do you know any good nou corresponding to the adjective handsome one doe not like to say beauty whe speaking of ma he ni beautiful enough heave know should not eve care to trust you nwith him faithfulest of all possible wife that you are whe he look nhis best a he always doe no do think the fascinatio of his nmanne ha much to do with it you recollect that the charm of art ninheres i that which is undefinable and to you and me my dea irene ni fancy there is rathe le of that i the branch of art unde nconsideratio tha to girl i thei first seaso fancy know how my nfine gentlema produce many of his effect and could perhaps give him npointe o heightening them nevertheless his manne is something truly ndelightful suppose what interest me chiefly is the ma brain his nconversatio is the best have eve heard and altogethe unlike any one nelse he seems to know everything a indeed he ought fo he ha bee neverywhere read everything see all there is to see sometimes think nrathe more tha is good fo him and had acquaintance with the n_queerest_ people and the his voice irene whe hea it actually nfeel a if ought to have paid at the doo though of course it is my now doo njuly 3 ni fea my remark about d barritz must have bee being thoughtless nvery silly o you would not have writte of him with such levity not nto say disrespect believe me dearest he ha more dignity and nseriousness of the kind mea which is not inconsistent with nmanne sometimes playful and always charming tha any of the me that nyou and eve met and young rayno you knew rayno at monterey tell nme that the me all like him and that he is treated with something like ndeference everywhere there is mystery too something about his nconnectio with the blavatsky people i northe india rayno eithe nwould not o could not tell me the particular infe that d barritz ni thought do you dare to laugh magicia could anything be nfine tha that na ordinary mystery is not of course so good a scandal but whe it nrelates to dark and dreadful practice to the exercise of unearthly npowers could anything be more piquant it explains too the singula ninfluence the ma ha upo me it is the undefinable i his art black nart seriously dea quite tremble whe he look me full i the eye nwith those unfathomable orb of his which have already vainly nattempted to describe to you how dreadful if he ha the powe to make none fall i love do you know if the blavatsky crowd have that powe noutside of sepoy njuly 16 nthe strangest thing last evening while auntie wa attending one of the nhotel hop hate them d barritz called it wa scandalously late nactually believe that he had talked with auntie i the ballroom and nlearned from he that wa alone had bee all the evening contriving nhow to worm out of him the truth about his connectio with the thug i nsepoy and all of that black business but the moment he fixed his eye no me fo admitted him m ashamed to say wa helpless ntrembled blushed o irene irene love the ma beyond expressio nand you know how it is yourself nfancy a ugly duckling from redhorse daughte they say of old ncalamity jim certainly his heiress with no living relatio but a nabsurd old aunt who spoil me thousand and fifty way absolutely ndestitute of everything but millio dollar and hope i paris ndaring to love god like him my dea if had you here could tea nyou hai out with mortificatio ni am convinced that he is aware of my feeling fo he stayed but few nmoments said nothing but what anothe ma might have said half a well nand pretending that he had a engagement went away learned to day nlittle bird told me the bell bird that he went straight to bed how ndoes that strike you a evidence of exemplary habit njuly 17 nthat little wretch rayno called yesterday and his babble set me nalmost wild he neve run dow that is to say whe he exterminates nscore of reputation more o le he doe not pause betwee one nreputatio and the next by the way he inquired about you and his nmanifestations of interest i you had confess good deal of n_vraisemblance _ m rayno observes no game law like death which nhe would inflict if slande were fatal he ha all season fo his ow nbut like him fo we knew each othe at redhorse whe we were young nhe wa know i those day a giggle and o irene ca you eve nforgive me wa called gunny god know why perhaps i allusio to nthe material of my pinafore perhaps because the name is i nalliteratio with giggle fo gig and were inseparable playmate nand the miner may have thought it delicate civility to recognize some nkind of relationship betwee u nlate we took i third anothe of adversity brood who like ngarrick betwee tragedy and comedy had chronic inability to nadjudicate the rival claim of frost and famine betwee him and misery nthere wa seldom anything more tha single suspende and the hope of nmeal which would at the same time support life and make it ninsupportable he literally picked up precarious living fo himself nand a aged mothe by chloriding the dump that is to say the miner npermitted him to search the heap of waste rock fo such piece of pay nore a had bee overlooked and these he sacked up and sold at the nsyndicate mill he became membe of ou firm gunny giggle and ndumps thenceforth through my favo fo could not the no ca nnow be indifferent to his courage and prowess i defending against ngiggles the immemorial right of his sex to insult strange and nunprotected female myself afte old jim struck it i the calamity and ni bega to wea shoe and go to school and i emulatio giggle took to nwashing his face and became jack rayno of well fargo co and old nmr bart wa herself chlorided to he father dump drifted ove to nsa jua smith and turned stage drive and wa killed by road agent nand so forth nwhy do tell you all this dea because it is heavy o my heart nbecause walk the valley of humility because am subduing myself to npermanent consciousness of my unworthiness to unloose the latchet of d nbarritz shoe because oh dea oh dea there a cousi of dump at nthis hotel have spoke to him neve had much acquaintance with nhim but do you suppose he ha recognized me do please give me i nyou next you candid sure enough opinio about it and say you do nthink so do you suppose he know about me already and that that is why nhe left me last evening whe he saw that blushed and trembled like nfool unde his eye you know ca bribe _all_ the newspaper and nca go back o anybody who wa civil to gunny at redhorse not if m npitched out of society into the sea so the skeleto sometimes rattle nbehind the doo neve cared much before a you know but now _now_ nit is not the same jack rayno am sure of he will not tell him he nseems indeed to hold him i such respect a hardly to dare speak to nhim at all and m good deal that way myself dea dea wish nhad something besides millio dollar if jack were three inch ntalle d marry him alive and go back to redhorse and wea sackcloth nagai to the end of my miserable day njuly 25 nwe had perfectly splendid sunset last evening and must tell you all nabout it ra away from auntie and everybody and wa walking alone o nthe beach expect you to believe you infidel that had not looked nout of my window o the seaward side of the hotel and see him walking nalone o the beach if you are not lost to every feeling of womanly ndelicacy you will accept my statement without questio soo nestablished myself unde my sunshade and had fo some time bee gazing nout dreamily ove the sea whe he approached walking close to the edge nof the wate it wa ebb tide assure you the wet sand actually nbrightened about his foot a he approached me he lifted his hat nsaying miss dement may sit with you o will you walk with me nthe possibility that neithe might be agreeable seems not to have noccurred to him did you eve know such assurance assurance my dea nit wa gall downright _gall _ well did find it wormwood and nreplied with my untutored redhorse heart i my throat i shall be npleased to do _anything_ could word have bee more stupid there are ndepths of fatuity i me friend my soul that are simply bottomless nhe extended his hand smiling and delivered mine into it without nmoment hesitatio and whe his finger closed about it to assist me nto my foot the consciousness that it trembled made me blush worse tha nthe red west got up howeve and afte while observing that he nhad not let go my hand pulled o it little but unsuccessfully he nsimply held o saying nothing but looking dow into my face with some nkind of smile did know how could whethe it wa affectionate nderisive o what fo did not look at him how beautiful he wa nwith the red fire of the sunset burning i the depth of his eye do nyou know dea if the thug and expert of the blavatsky regio have nany special kind of eye ah you should have see his superb attitude nthe god like inclinatio of his head a he stood ove me afte had got nupo my foot it wa noble picture but soo destroyed it fo nbega at once to sink agai to the earth there wa only one thing fo nhim to do and he did it he supported me with a arm about my waist miss dement are you ill he said nit wa not a exclamatio there wa neithe alarm no solicitude i it nif he had added suppose that is about what am expected to say he nwould hardly have expressed his sense of the situatio more clearly his nmanne filled me with shame and indignatio fo wa suffering nacutely wrenched my hand out of his grasped the arm supporting me nand pushing myself free fell plump into the sand and sat helpless my nhat had falle off i the struggle and my hai tumbled about my face and nshoulders i the most mortifying way go away from me cried half choking _please_ go away you you nthug how dare you think _that_ whe my leg is asleep ni actually said those identical word and the broke dow and sobbed nirene _blubbered_ nhis manne altered i a instant could see that much through my nfingers and hai he dropped o one knee beside me parted the tangle of nhai and said i the tenderest way my poo girl god know have not nintended to pai you how should i who love you who have loved nyou fo fo year and year nhe had pulled my wet hand away from my face and wa covering them with nkisses my cheek were like two coal my whole face wa flaming and nthink steaming what could do hid it o his shoulde there wa no nothe place and my dea friend how my leg tingled and thrilled and nhow wanted to kick nwe sat so fo long time he had released one of my hand to pas his narm about me agai and possessed myself of my handkerchief and wa ndrying my eye and my nose would not look up until that wa done he ntried i vai to push me little away and gaze into my face presently nwhe all wa right and it had grow bit dark lifted my head nlooked him straight i the eye and smiled my best my level best dea what do you mea said by year and year dearest he replied very gravely very earnestly i the absence of nthe sunke cheek the hollow eye the lank hai the slouching gait nthe rag dirt and youth ca you not will you not understand gunny ni dump ni moment wa upo my foot and he upo his seized him by the nlapels of his coat and peered into his handsome face i the deepening ndarkness wa breathless with excitement and you are not dead asked hardly knowing what said only dead i love dea recovered have roped i you affectionate friend mary jane dement np the worst of it is that there is no mystery that wa the ninventio of jack rayno to arouse my curiosity james is not thug nhe solemnly assures me that i all his wandering he ha neve set foot ni sepoy nthe eye of the panthe ni none doe not always marry whe insane na ma and woma nature had done the grouping sat o rustic seat ni the late
